the blazing temples of their gods. Her sister

1695.text:
hears; and, furious with despair, She beats
her breast, and rends her yellow hair, And,

1702.text:
calling on Eliza's name aloud, Runs breathless
to the place, and breaks the crowd. "Was all

1709.text:
that pomp of woe for this prepar'd; These
fires, this fun'ral pile, these altars rear'd?

1716.text:
Was all this train of plots contriv'd," said
she, "All only to deceive unhappy me? Which

1724.text:
is the worst? Didst thou in death pretend
To scorn thy sister, or delude thy friend?

1733.text:
Thy summon'd sister, and thy friend, had come;
One sword had serv'd us both, one common tomb:

1741.text:
Was I to raise the pile, the pow'rs invoke,
Not to be present at the fatal stroke? At

1749.text:
once thou hast destroy'd thyself and me, Thy
town, thy senate, and thy colony! Bring water;

1759.text:
bathe the wound; while I in death Lay close
my lips to hers, and catch the flying breath."

1764.text:
This said, she mounts the pile with eager
haste, And in her arms the gasping queen embrac'd;

1772.text:
Her temples chaf'd; and her own garments tore,
To stanch the streaming blood, and cleanse

1777.text:
the gore. Thrice Dido tried to raise her drooping
head, And, fainting thrice, fell grov'ling

1784.text:
on the bed; Thrice op'd her heavy eyes, and
sought the light, But, having found it, sicken'd

1791.text:
at the sight, And clos'd her lids at last
in endless night. Then Juno, grieving that

1800.text:
she should sustain A death so ling'ring, and
so full of pain, Sent Iris down, to free her

1807.text:
from the strife Of lab'ring nature, and dissolve
her life. For since she died, not doom'd by

1814.text:
Heav'n's decree, Or her own crime, but human
casualty, And rage of love, that plung'd her

1821.text:
in despair, The Sisters had not cut the topmost
hair, Which Proserpine and they can only know;

1828.text:
Nor made her sacred to the shades below. Downward
the various goddess took her flight, And drew

1835.text:
a thousand colors from the light; Then stood
above the dying lover's head, And said: "I

1843.text:
thus devote thee to the dead. This off'ring
to th' infernal gods I bear." Thus while she

1851.text:
spoke, she cut the fatal hair: The struggling
soul was loos'd, and life dissolv'd in air.

1861.text:
End of Book IV Book V, Games and a Conflagration
Part I Meantime the Trojan cuts his wat'ry

1875.text:
way, Fix'd on his voyage, thro' the curling
sea; Then, casting back his eyes, with dire

1883.text:
amaze, Sees on the Punic shore the mounting
blaze. The cause unknown; yet his presaging

1893.text:
mind The fate of Dido from the fire divin'd;
He knew the stormy souls of womankind, What

1902.text:
secret springs their eager passions move,
How capable of death for injur'd love. Dire

1912.text:
auguries from hence the Trojans draw; Till
neither fires nor shining shores they saw.

1920.text:
Now seas and skies their prospect only bound;
An empty space above, a floating field around.

1930.text:
But soon the heav'ns with shadows were o'erspread;
A swelling cloud hung hov'ring o'er their

1938.text:
head: Livid it look'd, the threat'ning of
a storm: Then night and horror ocean's face

1946.text:
deform. The pilot, Palinurus, cried aloud:
"What gusts of weather from that gath'ring

1953.text:
cloud My thoughts presage! Ere yet the tempest
roars, Stand to your tackle, mates, and stretch

1963.text:
your oars; Contract your swelling sails, and
luff to wind." The frighted crew perform the

1972.text:
task assign'd. Then, to his fearless chief:
"Not Heav'n," said he, "Tho' Jove himself

1981.text:
should promise Italy, Can stem the torrent
of this raging sea. Mark how the shifting

1989.text:
winds from west arise, And what collected
night involves the skies! Nor can our shaken

1997.text:
vessels live at sea, Much less against the
tempest force their way. 'T is fate diverts

2004.text:
our course, and fate we must obey. Not far
from hence, if I observ'd aright The southing

2011.text:
of the stars, and polar light, Sicilia lies,
whose hospitable shores In safety we may reach

2020.text:
with struggling oars." Aeneas then replied:
"Too sure I find We strive in vain against

2029.text:
the seas and wind: Now shift your sails; what
place can please me more Than what you promise,

2037.text:
the Sicilian shore, Whose hallow'd earth Anchises'
bones contains, And where a prince of Trojan

2046.text:
lineage reigns?" The course resolv'd, before
the western wind They scud amain, and make

2054.text:
the port assign'd. Meantime Acestes, from
a lofty stand, Beheld the fleet descending

2060.text:
on the land; And, not unmindful of his ancient
race, Down from the cliff he ran with eager

2070.text:
pace, And held the hero in a strict embrace.
Of a rough Libyan bear the spoils he wore,

2079.text:
And either hand a pointed jav'lin bore. His
mother was a dame of Dardan blood; His sire

2087.text:
Crinisus, a Sicilian flood. He welcomes his
returning friends ashore With plenteous country

2096.text:
cates and homely store. Now, when the following
morn had chas'd away The flying stars, and

2104.text:
light restor'd the day, Aeneas call'd the
Trojan troops around, And thus bespoke them

2112.text:
from a rising ground: "Offspring of heav'n,
divine Dardanian race! The sun, revolving

2121.text:
thro' th' ethereal space, The shining circle
of the year has fill'd, Since first this isle

2129.text:
my father's ashes held: And now the rising
day renews the year; A day for ever sad, for

2139.text:
ever dear. This would I celebrate with annual
games, With gifts on altars pil'd, and holy

2147.text:
flames, Tho' banish'd to Gaetulia's barren
sands, Caught on the Grecian seas, or hostile

2155.text:
lands: But since this happy storm our fleet
has driv'n (Not, as I deem, without the will

2164.text:
of Heav'n) Upon these friendly shores and
flow'ry plains, Which hide Anchises and his

2172.text:
blest remains, Let us with joy perform his
honors due, And pray for prosp'rous winds,

2180.text:
our voyage to renew; Pray, that in towns and
temples of our own, The name of great Anchises

2188.text:
may be known, And yearly games may spread
the gods' renown. Our sports Acestes, of the

2200.text:
Trojan race, With royal gifts ordain'd, is
pleas'd to grace: Two steers on ev'ry ship

2206.text:
the king bestows; His gods and ours shall
share your equal vows. Besides, if, nine days

2216.text:
hence, the rosy morn Shall with unclouded
light the skies adorn, That day with solemn

2224.text:
sports I mean to grace: Light galleys on the
seas shall run a wat'ry race; Some shall in

2232.text:
swiftness for the goal contend, And others
try the twanging bow to bend; The strong,

2240.text:
with iron gauntlets arm'd, shall stand Oppos'd
in combat on the yellow sand. Let all be present

2248.text:
at the games prepar'd, And joyful victors
wait the just reward. But now assist the rites,

2256.text:
with garlands crown'd." He said, and first
his brows with myrtle bound. Then Helymus,

2262.text:
by his example led, And old Acestes, each
adorn'd his head; Thus young Ascanius, with

2270.text:
a sprightly grace, His temples tied, and all
the Trojan race. Aeneas then advanc'd amidst

2277.text:
the train, By thousands follow'd thro' the
flow'ry plain, To great Anchises' tomb; which

2285.text:
when he found, He pour'd to Bacchus, on the
hallow'd ground, Two bowls of sparkling wine,

2291.text:
of milk two more, And two (from offer'd bulls)
of purple gore, With roses then the sepulcher

2299.text:
he strow'd And thus his father's ghost bespoke
aloud: "Hail, O ye holy manes! hail again,

2308.text:
Paternal ashes, now review'd in vain! The
gods permitted not, that you, with me, Should

2317.text:
reach the promis'd shores of Italy, Or Tiber's
flood, what flood soe'er it be." Scarce had

2325.text:
he finish'd, when, with speckled pride, A
serpent from the tomb began to glide; His

2332.text:
hugy bulk on sev'n high volumes roll'd; Blue
was his breadth of back, but streak'd with

2339.text:
scaly gold: Thus riding on his curls, he seem'd
to pass A rolling fire along, and singe the

2345.text:
grass. More various colors thro' his body
run, Than Iris when her bow imbibes the sun.

2353.text:
Betwixt the rising altars, and around, The
sacred monster shot along the ground; With

2360.text:
harmless play amidst the bowls he pass'd,
And with his lolling tongue assay'd the taste:

2365.text:
Thus fed with holy food, the wondrous guest
Within the hollow tomb retir'd to rest. The

2374.text:
pious prince, surpris'd at what he view'd,
The fun'ral honors with more zeal renew'd,

2383.text:
Doubtful if this place's genius were, Or guardian
of his father's sepulcher. Five sheep, according

2390.text:
to the rites, he slew; As many swine, and
steers of sable hue; New gen'rous wine he

2399.text:
from the goblets pour'd. And call'd his father's
ghost, from hell restor'd. The glad attendants

2406.text:
in long order come, Off'ring their gifts at
great Anchises' tomb: Some add more oxen:

2413.text:
some divide the spoil; Some place the chargers
on the grassy soil; Some blow the fires, and

2422.text:
offered entrails broil. Now came the day desir'd.
The skies were bright With rosy luster of

2431.text:
the rising light: The bord'ring people, rous'd
by sounding fame Of Trojan feasts and great

2438.text:
Acestes' name, The crowded shore with acclamations
fill, Part to behold, and part to prove their

2448.text:
skill. And first the gifts in public view
they place, Green laurel wreaths, and palm,

2455.text:
the victors' grace: Within the circle, arms
and tripods lie, Ingots of gold and silver,

2462.text:
heap'd on high, And vests embroider'd, of
the Tyrian dye. The trumpet's clangor then

2470.text:
the feast proclaims, And all prepare for their
appointed games. Four galleys first, which

2477.text:
equal rowers bear, Advancing, in the wat'ry
lists appear. The speedy Dolphin, that outstrips

2486.text:
the wind, Bore Mnestheus, author of the Memmian
kind: Gyas the vast Chimaera's bulk commands,

2494.text:
Which rising, like a tow'ring city stands;
Three Trojans tug at ev'ry lab'ring oar; Three

2503.text:
banks in three degrees the sailors bore; Beneath
their sturdy strokes the billows roar. Sergesthus,

2511.text:
who began the Sergian race, In the great Centaur
took the leading place; Cloanthus on the sea-green

2522.text:
Scylla stood, From whom Cluentius draws his
Trojan blood. Far in the sea, against the

2529.text:
foaming shore, There stands a rock: the raging
billows roar Above his head in storms; but,

2537.text:
when 't is clear, Uncurl their ridgy backs,
and at his foot appear. In peace below the

2544.text:
gentle waters run; The cormorants above lie
basking in the sun. On this the hero fix'd

2552.text:
an oak in sight, The mark to guide the mariners
aright. To bear with this, the seamen stretch

2560.text:
their oars; Then round the rock they steer,
and seek the former shores. The lots decide

2568.text:
their place. Above the rest, Each leader shining
in his Tyrian vest; The common crew with wreaths

2578.text:
of poplar boughs Their temples crown, and
shade their sweaty brows: Besmear'd with oil,

2586.text:
their naked shoulders shine. All take their
seats, and wait the sounding sign: They gripe

2594.text:
their oars; and ev'ry panting breast Is rais'd
by turns with hope, by turns with fear depress'd.

2602.text:
The clangor of the trumpet gives the sign;
At once they start, advancing in a line: With

2610.text:
shouts the sailors rend the starry skies;
Lash'd with their oars, the smoky billows

2617.text:
rise; Sparkles the briny main, and the vex'd
ocean fries. Exact in time, with equal strokes

2629.text:
they row: At once the brushing oars and brazen
prow Dash up the sandy waves, and ope the

2638.text:
depths below. Not fiery coursers, in a chariot
race, Invade the field with half so swift

2646.text:
a pace; Not the fierce driver with more fury
lends The sounding lash, and, ere the stroke

2653.text:
descends, Low to the wheels his pliant body
bends. The partial crowd their hopes and fears

2662.text:
divide, And aid with eager shouts the favor'd
side. Cries, murmurs, clamors, with a mixing

2668.text:
sound, From woods to woods, from hills to
hills rebound. Amidst the loud applauses of

2677.text:
the shore, Gyas outstripp'd the rest, and
sprung before: Cloanthus, better mann'd, pursued

2684.text:
him fast, But his o'er-masted galley check'd
his haste. The Centaur and the Dolphin brush

2691.text:
the brine With equal oars, advancing in a
line; And now the mighty Centaur seems to

2698.text:
lead, And now the speedy Dolphin gets ahead;
Now board to board the rival vessels row,

2705.text:
The billows lave the skies, and ocean groans
below. They reach'd the mark. Proud Gyas and

2712.text:
his train In triumph rode, the victors of
the main; But, steering round, he charg'd

2719.text:
his pilot stand More close to shore, and skim
along the sand- "Let others bear to sea!"

2728.text:
Menoetes heard; But secret shelves too cautiously
he fear'd, And, fearing, sought the deep;

2735.text:
and still aloof he steer'd. With louder cries
the captain call'd again: "Bear to the rocky

2742.text:
shore, and shun the main." He spoke, and,
speaking, at his stern he saw The bold Cloanthus

2750.text:
near the shelvings draw. Betwixt the mark
and him the Scylla stood, And in a closer

2757.text:
compass plow'd the flood. He pass'd the mark;
and, wheeling, got before: Gyas blasphem'd

2768.text:
the gods, devoutly swore, Cried out for anger,
and his hair he tore. Mindless of others'

2773.text:
lives (so high was grown His rising rage)
and careless of his own, The trembling dotard

2780.text:
to the deck he drew; Then hoisted up, and
overboard he threw: This done, he seiz'd the

2788.text:
helm; his fellows cheer'd, Turn'd short upon
the shelfs, and madly steer'd. Hardly his

2796.text:
head the plunging pilot rears, Clogg'd with
his clothes, and cumber'd with his years:

2802.text:
Now dropping wet, he climbs the cliff with
pain. The crowd, that saw him fall and float

2811.text:
again, Shout from the distant shore; and loudly
laugh'd, To see his heaving breast disgorge

2816.text:
the briny draught. The following Centaur,
and the Dolphin's crew, Their vanish'd hopes

2823.text:
of victory renew; While Gyas lags, they kindle
in the race, To reach the mark. Sergesthus

2830.text:
takes the place; Mnestheus pursues; and while
around they wind, Comes up, not half his galley's

2838.text:
length behind; Then, on the deck, amidst his
mates appear'd, And thus their drooping courage

2845.text:
he cheer'd: "My friends, and Hector's followers
heretofore, Exert your vigor; tug the lab'ring

2853.text:
oar; Stretch to your strokes, my still unconquer'd
crew, Whom from the flaming walls of Troy

2861.text:
I drew. In this, our common int'rest, let
me find That strength of hand, that courage

2867.text:
of the mind, As when you stemm'd the strong
Malean flood, And o'er the Syrtes' broken

2874.text:
billows row'd. I seek not now the foremost
palm to gain; Tho' yet- but, ah! that haughty

2882.text:
wish is vain! Let those enjoy it whom the
gods ordain. But to be last, the lags of all

2891.text:
the race!- Redeem yourselves and me from that
disgrace." Now, one and all, they tug amain;

2900.text:
they row At the full stretch, and shake the
brazen prow. The sea beneath 'em sinks; their

2908.text:
lab'ring sides Are swell'd, and sweat runs
gutt'ring down in tides. Chance aids their

2916.text:
daring with unhop'd success; Sergesthus, eager
with his beak to press Betwixt the rival galley

2923.text:
and the rock, Shuts up th' unwieldly Centaur
in the lock. The vessel struck; and, with

2931.text:
the dreadful shock, Her oars she shiver'd,
and her head she broke. The trembling rowers

2938.text:
from their banks arise, And, anxious for themselves,
renounce the prize. With iron poles they heave

2946.text:
her off the shores, And gather from the sea
their floating oars. The crew of Mnestheus,

2953.text:
with elated minds, Urge their success, and
call the willing winds; Then ply their oars,

2959.text:
and cut their liquid way In larger compass
on the roomy sea. As, when the dove her rocky

2966.text:
hold forsakes, Rous'd in a fright, her sounding
wings she shakes; The cavern rings with clatt'ring;

2974.text:
out she flies, And leaves her callow care,
and cleaves the skies: At first she flutters;

2981.text:
but at length she springs To smoother flight,
and shoots upon her wings: So Mnestheus in

2988.text:
the Dolphin cuts the sea; And, flying with
a force, that force assists his way. Sergesthus

2995.text:
in the Centaur soon he pass'd, Wedg'd in the
rocky shoals, and sticking fast. In vain the

3003.text:
victor he with cries implores, And practices
to row with shatter'd oars. Then Mnestheus

3010.text:
bears with Gyas, and outflies: The ship, without
a pilot, yields the prize. Unvanquish'd Scylla

3017.text:
now alone remains; Her he pursues, and all
his vigor strains. Shouts from the fav'ring

3026.text:
multitude arise; Applauding Echo to the shouts
replies; Shouts, wishes, and applause run

3034.text:
rattling thro' the skies. These clamors with
disdain the Scylla heard, Much grudg'd the

3042.text:
praise, but more the robb'd reward: Resolv'd
to hold their own, they mend their pace, All

3048.text:
obstinate to die, or gain the race. Rais'd
with success, the Dolphin swiftly ran; For

3055.text:
they can conquer, who believe they can. Both
urge their oars, and fortune both supplies,

3063.text:
And both perhaps had shar'd an equal prize;
When to the seas Cloanthus holds his hands,

3070.text:
And succor from the wat'ry pow'rs demands:
"Gods of the liquid realms, on which I row!

3077.text:
If, giv'n by you, the laurel bind my brow,
Assist to make me guilty of my vow! A snow-white

3087.text:
bull shall on your shore be slain; His offer'd
entrails cast into the main, And ruddy wine,

3096.text:
from golden goblets thrown, Your grateful
gift and my return shall own." The choir of

3103.text:
nymphs, and Phorcus, from below, With virgin
Panopea, heard his vow; And old Portunus,

3112.text:
with his breadth of hand, Push'd on, and sped
the galley to the land. Swift as a shaft,

3119.text:
or winged wind, she flies, And, darting to
the port, obtains the prize. The herald summons

3129.text:
all, and then proclaims Cloanthus conqu'ror
of the naval games. The prince with laurel

3139.text:
crowns the victor's head, And three fat steers
are to his vessel led, The ship's reward;

3146.text:
with gen'rous wine beside, And sums of silver,
which the crew divide. The leaders are distinguish'd

3152.text:
from the rest; The victor honor'd with a nobler
vest, Where gold and purple strive in equal

3160.text:
rows, And needlework its happy cost bestows.
There Ganymede is wrought with living art,

3167.text:
Chasing thro' Ida's groves the trembling hart:
Breathless he seems, yet eager to pursue;

3174.text:
When from aloft descends, in open view, The
bird of Jove, and, sousing on his prey, With

3182.text:
crooked talons bears the boy away. In vain,
with lifted hands and gazing eyes, His guards

3190.text:
behold him soaring thro' the skies, And dogs
pursue his flight with imitated cries. Mnestheus

3199.text:
the second victor was declar'd; And, summon'd
there, the second prize he shard. A coat of

3206.text:
mail, brave Demoleus bore, More brave Aeneas
from his shoulders tore, In single combat

3214.text:
on the Trojan shore: This was ordain'd for
Mnestheus to possess; In war for his defense,

3222.text:
for ornament in peace. Rich was the gift,
and glorious to behold, But yet so pond'rous

3230.text:
with its plates of gold, That scarce two servants
could the weight sustain; Yet, loaded thus,

3237.text:
Demoleus o'er the plain Pursued and lightly
seiz'd the Trojan train. The third, succeeding

3244.text:
to the last reward, Two goodly bowls of massy
silver shar'd, With figures prominent, and

3251.text:
richly wrought, And two brass caldrons from
Dodona brought. Thus all, rewarded by the

3258.text:
hero's hands, Their conqu'ring temples bound
with purple bands; And now Sergesthus, clearing

3266.text:
from the rock, Brought back his galley shatter'd
with the shock. Forlorn she look'd, without

3273.text:
an aiding oar, And, houted by the vulgar,
made to shore. As when a snake, surpris'd

3280.text:
upon the road, Is crush'd athwart her body
by the load Of heavy wheels; or with a mortal

3285.text:
wound Her belly bruis'd, and trodden to the
ground: In vain, with loosen'd curls, she

3291.text:
crawls along; Yet, fierce above, she brandishes
her tongue; Glares with her eyes, and bristles

3298.text:
with her scales; But, groveling in the dust,
her parts unsound she trails: So slowly to

3308.text:
the port the Centaur tends, But, what she
wants in oars, with sails amends. Yet, for

3317.text:
his galley sav'd, the grateful prince Is pleas'd
th' unhappy chief to recompense. Pholoe, the

3325.text:
Cretan slave, rewards his care, Beauteous
herself, with lovely twins as fair. From thence

3335.text:
his way the Trojan hero bent Into the neighb'ring
plain, with mountains pent, Whose sides were

3342.text:
shaded with surrounding wood. Full in the
midst of this fair valley stood A native theater,

3350.text:
which, rising slow By just degrees, o'erlook'd
the ground below. High on a sylvan throne

3360.text:
the leader sate; A num'rous train attend in
solemn state. Here those that in the rapid

3366.text:
course delight, Desire of honor and the prize
invite. The rival runners without order stand;

3374.text:
The Trojans mix'd with the Sicilian band.
First Nisus, with Euryalus, appears; Euryalus

3382.text:
a boy of blooming years, With sprightly grace
and equal beauty crown'd; Nisus, for friendship

3392.text:
to the youth renown'd. Diores next, of Priam's
royal race, Then Salius joined with Patron,

3400.text:
took their place; (But Patron in Arcadia had
his birth, And Salius his from Arcananian

3408.text:
earth;) Then two Sicilian youths- the names
of these, Swift Helymus, and lovely Panopes:

3415.text:
Both jolly huntsmen, both in forest bred,
And owning old Acestes for their head; With

3422.text:
sev'ral others of ignobler name, Whom time
has not deliver'd o'er to fame. To these the

3429.text:
hero thus his thoughts explain'd, In words
which gen'ral approbation gain'd: "One common

3435.text:
largess is for all design'd, (The vanquish'd
and the victor shall be join'd,) Two darts

3441.text:
of polish'd steel and Gnosian wood, A silver-studded
ax, alike bestow'd. The foremost three have

3450.text:
olive wreaths decreed: The first of these
obtains a stately steed, Adorn'd with trappings;

3457.text:
and the next in fame, The quiver of an Amazonian
dame, With feather'd Thracian arrows well

3465.text:
supplied: A golden belt shall gird his manly
side, Which with a sparkling diamond shall

3472.text:
be tied. The third this Grecian helmet shall
content." He said. To their appointed base

3480.text:
they went; With beating hearts th' expected
sign receive, And, starting all at once, the

3485.text:
barrier leave. Spread out, as on the winged
winds, they flew, And seiz'd the distant goal

3493.text:
with greedy view. Shot from the crowd, swift
Nisus all o'erpass'd; Nor storms, nor thunder,

3503.text:
equal half his haste. The next, but tho' the
next, yet far disjoin'd, Came Salius, and

3512.text:
Euryalus behind; Then Helymus, whom young
Diores plied, Step after step, and almost

3520.text:
side by side, His shoulders pressing; and,
in longer space, Had won, or left at least

3529.text:
a dubious race. Now, spent, the goal they
almost reach at last, When eager Nisus, hapless

3538.text:
in his haste, Slipp'd first, and, slipping,
fell upon the plain, Soak'd with the blood

3545.text:
of oxen newly slain. The careless victor had
not mark'd his way; But, treading where the

3552.text:
treach'rous puddle lay, His heels flew up;
and on the grassy floor He fell, besmear'd

3559.text:
with filth and holy gore. Not mindless then,
Euryalus, of thee, Nor of the sacred bonds

3567.text:
of amity, He strove th' immediate rival's
hope to cross, And caught the foot of Salius

3574.text:
as he rose. So Salius lay extended on the
plain; Euryalus springs out, the prize to

3582.text:
gain, And leaves the crowd: applauding peals
attend The victor to the goal, who vanquish'd

3590.text:
by his friend. Next Helymus; and then Diores
came, By two misfortunes made the third in

3600.text:
fame. But Salius enters, and, exclaiming loud
For justice, deafens and disturbs the crowd;

3609.text:
Urges his cause may in the court be heard;
And pleads the prize is wrongfully conferr'd.

3616.text:
But favor for Euryalus appears; His blooming
beauty, with his tender tears, Had brib'd

3622.text:
the judges for the promis'd prize. Besides,
Diores fills the court with cries, Who vainly

3630.text:
reaches at the last reward, If the first palm
on Salius be conferr'd. Then thus the prince:

3637.text:
"Let no disputes arise: Where fortune plac'd
it, I award the prize. But fortune's errors

3644.text:
give me leave to mend, At least to pity my
deserving friend." He said, and, from among

3651.text:
the spoils, he draws (Pond'rous with shaggy
mane and golden paws) A lion's hide: to Salius

3658.text:
this he gives. Nisus with envy sees the gift,
and grieves. "If such rewards to vanquish'd

3665.text:
men are due." He said, "and falling is to
rise by you, What prize may Nisus from your

3673.text:
bounty claim, Who merited the first rewards
and fame? In falling, both an equal fortune

3679.text:
tried; Would fortune for my fall so well provide!"
With this he pointed to his face, and show'd

3687.text:
His hand and all his habit smear'd with blood.
Th' indulgent father of the people smil'd,

3693.text:
And caus'd to be produc'd an ample shield,
Of wondrous art, by Didymaon wrought, Long

3700.text:
since from Neptune's bars in triumph brought.
This giv'n to Nisus, he divides the rest,

3710.text:
And equal justice in his gifts express'd.
The race thus ended, and rewards bestow'd,

3717.text:
Once more the prince bespeaks th' attentive
crowd: "If there he here whose dauntless courage

3723.text:
dare In gauntlet-fight, with limbs and body
bare, His opposite sustain in open view, Stand

3730.text:
forth the champion, and the games renew. Two
prizes I propose, and thus divide: A bull

3737.text:
with gilded horns, and fillets tied, Shall
be the portion of the conqu'ring chief; A

3744.text:
sword and helm shall cheer the loser's grief."
Then haughty Dares in the lists appears; Stalking

3753.text:
he strides, his head erected bears: His nervous
arms the weighty gauntlet wield, And loud

3761.text:
applauses echo thro' the field. Dares alone
in combat us'd to stand The match of mighty

3769.text:
Paris, hand to hand; The same, at Hector's
fun'rals, undertook Gigantic Butes, of th'

3777.text:
Amycian stock, And, by the stroke of his resistless
hand, Stretch'd the vast bulk upon the yellow

3785.text:
sand. Such Dares was; and such he strode along,
And drew the wonder of the gazing throng.

3793.text:
His brawny back and ample breast he shows,
His lifted arms around his head he throws,

3800.text:
And deals in whistling air his empty blows.
His match is sought; but, thro' the trembling

3807.text:
band, Not one dares answer to the proud demand.
Presuming of his force, with sparkling eyes

3815.text:
Already he devours the promis'd prize. He
claims the bull with awless insolence, And

3824.text:
having seiz'd his horns, accosts the prince:
"If none my matchless valor dares oppose,

3832.text:
How long shall Dares wait his dastard foes?
Permit me, chief, permit without delay, To

3840.text:
lead this uncontended gift away." The crowd
assents, and with redoubled cries For the

3847.text:
proud challenger demands the prize. End of
Book V, Part I Book V, Games and a Conflagration

3863.text:
Part II Acestes, fir'd with just disdain,
to see The palm usurp'd without a victory,

3872.text:
Reproach'd Entellus thus, who sate beside,
And heard and saw, unmov'd, the Trojan's pride:

3881.text:
"Once, but in vain, a champion of renown,
So tamely can you bear the ravish'd crown,

3889.text:
A prize in triumph borne before your sight,
And shun, for fear, the danger of the fight?

3898.text:
Where is our Eryx now, the boasted name, The
god who taught your thund'ring arm the game?

3908.text:
Where now your baffled honor? Where the spoil
That fill'd your house, and fame that fill'd

3914.text:
our isle?" Entellus, thus: "My soul is still
the same, Unmov'd with fear, and mov'd with

3924.text:
martial fame; But my chill blood is curdled
in my veins, And scarce the shadow of a man

3933.text:
remains. O could I turn to that fair prime
again, That prime of which this boaster is

3939.text:
so vain, The brave, who this decrepid age
defies, Should feel my force, without the

3947.text:
promis'd prize." He said; and, rising at the
word, he threw Two pond'rous gauntlets down

3955.text:
in open view; Gauntlets which Eryx wont in
fight to wield, And sheathe his hands with

3962.text:
in the listed field. With fear and wonder
seiz'd, the crowd beholds The gloves of death,

3970.text:
with sev'n distinguish'd folds Of tough bull
hides; the space within is spread With iron,

3978.text:
or with loads of heavy lead: Dares himself
was daunted at the sight, Renounc'd his challenge,

3986.text:
and refus'd to fight. Astonish'd at their
weight, the hero stands, And pois'd the pond'rous

3993.text:
engines in his hands. "What had your wonder,"
said Entellus, "been, Had you the gauntlets

4001.text:
of Alcides seen, Or view'd the stern debate
on this unhappy green! These which I bear

4010.text:
your brother Eryx bore, Still mark'd with
batter'd brains and mingled gore. With these

4018.text:
he long sustain'd th' Herculean arm; And these
I wielded while my blood was warm, This languish'd

4028.text:
frame while better spirits fed, Ere age unstrung
my nerves, or time o'ersnow'd my head. But

4038.text:
if the challenger these arms refuse, And cannot
wield their weight, or dare not use; If great

4045.text:
Aeneas and Acestes join In his request, these
gauntlets I resign; Let us with equal arms

4053.text:
perform the fight, And let him leave to fear,
since I resign my right." This said, Entellus

4062.text:
for the strife prepares; Stripp'd of his quilted
coat, his body bares; Compos'd of mighty bones

4070.text:
and brawn he stands, A goodly tow'ring object
on the sands. Then just Aeneas equal arms

4080.text:
supplied, Which round their shoulders to their
wrists they tied. Both on the tiptoe stand,

4087.text:
at full extent, Their arms aloft, their bodies
inly bent; Their heads from aiming blows they

4094.text:
bear afar; With clashing gauntlets then provoke
the war. One on his youth and pliant limbs

4103.text:
relies; One on his sinews and his giant size.
The last is stiff with age, his motion slow;

4113.text:
He heaves for breath, he staggers to and fro,
And clouds of issuing smoke his nostrils loudly

4122.text:
blow. Yet equal in success, they ward, they
strike; Their ways are diff'rent, but their

4130.text:
art alike. Before, behind, the blows are dealt;
around Their hollow sides the rattling thumps

4139.text:
resound. A storm of strokes, well meant, with
fury flies, And errs about their temples,

4147.text:
ears, and eyes. Nor always errs; for oft the
gauntlet draws A sweeping stroke along the

4156.text:
crackling jaws. Heavy with age, Entellus stands
his ground, But with his warping body wards

4165.text:
the wound. His hand and watchful eye keep
even pace; While Dares traverses and shifts

4173.text:
his place, And, like a captain who beleaguers
round Some strong-built castle on a rising

4182.text:
ground, Views all th' approaches with observing
eyes: This and that other part in vain he

4189.text:
tries, And more on industry than force relies.
With hands on high, Entellus threats the foe;

4199.text:
But Dares watch'd the motion from below, And
slipp'd aside, and shunn'd the long descending

4206.text:
blow. Entellus wastes his forces on the wind,
And, thus deluded of the stroke design'd,

4214.text:
Headlong and heavy fell; his ample breast
And weighty limbs his ancient mother press'd.

4221.text:
So falls a hollow pine, that long had stood
On Ida's height, or Erymanthus' wood, Torn

4228.text:
from the roots. The diff'ring nations rise,
And shouts and mingled murmurs rend the skies,

4235.text:
Acestus runs with eager haste, to raise The
fall'n companion of his youthful days. Dauntless

4241.text:
he rose, and to the fight return'd; With shame
his glowing cheeks, his eyes with fury burn'd.

4249.text:
Disdain and conscious virtue fir'd his breast,
And with redoubled force his foe he press'd.

4257.text:
He lays on load with either hand, amain, And
headlong drives the Trojan o'er the plain;

4266.text:
Nor stops, nor stays; nor rest nor breath
allows; But storms of strokes descend about

4275.text:
his brows, A rattling tempest, and a hail
of blows. But now the prince, who saw the

4282.text:
wild increase Of wounds, commands the combatants
to cease, And bounds Entellus' wrath, and

4289.text:
bids the peace. First to the Trojan, spent
with toil, he came, And sooth'd his sorrow

4297.text:
for the suffer'd shame. "What fury seiz'd
my friend? The gods," said he, "To him propitious,

4304.text:
and averse to thee, Have giv'n his arm superior
force to thine. 'T is madness to contend with

4312.text:
strength divine." The gauntlet fight thus
ended, from the shore His faithful friends

4318.text:
unhappy Dares bore: His mouth and nostrils
pour'd a purple flood, And pounded teeth came

4326.text:
rushing with his blood. Faintly he stagger'd
thro' the hissing throng, And hung his head,

4333.text:
and trail'd his legs along. The sword and
casque are carried by his train; But with

4339.text:
his foe the palm and ox remain. The champion,
then, before Aeneas came, Proud of his prize,

4349.text:
but prouder of his fame: "O goddess-born,
and you, Dardanian host, Mark with attention,

4356.text:
and forgive my boast; Learn what I was, by
what remains; and know From what impending

4363.text:
fate you sav'd my foe." Sternly he spoke,
and then confronts the bull; And, on his ample

4371.text:
forehead aiming full, The deadly stroke, descending,
pierc'd the skull. Down drops the beast, nor

4380.text:
needs a second wound, But sprawls in pangs
of death, and spurns the ground. Then, thus:

4388.text:
"In Dares' stead I offer this. Eryx, accept
a nobler sacrifice; Take the last gift my

4397.text:
wither'd arms can yield: Thy gauntlets I resign,
and here renounce the field." This done, Aeneas

4406.text:
orders, for the close, The strife of archers
with contending bows. The mast Sergesthus'

4413.text:
shatter'd galley bore With his own hands he
raises on the shore. A flutt'ring dove upon

4420.text:
the top they tie, The living mark at which
their arrows fly. The rival archers in a line

4428.text:
advance, Their turn of shooting to receive
from chance. A helmet holds their names; the

4435.text:
lots are drawn: On the first scroll was read
Hippocoon. The people shout. Upon the next

4443.text:
was found Young Mnestheus, late with naval
honors crown'd. The third contain'd Eurytion's

4452.text:
noble name, Thy brother, Pandarus, and next
in fame, Whom Pallas urg'd the treaty to confound,

4460.text:
And send among the Greeks a feather'd wound.
Acestes in the bottom last remain'd, Whom

4468.text:
not his age from youthful sports restrain'd.
Soon all with vigor bend their trusty bows,

4476.text:
And from the quiver each his arrow chose.
Hippocoon's was the first: with forceful sway

4485.text:
It flew, and, whizzing, cut the liquid way.
Fix'd in the mast the feather'd weapon stands:

4494.text:
The fearful pigeon flutters in her bands,
And the tree trembled, and the shouting cries

4501.text:
Of the pleas'd people rend the vaulted skies.
Then Mnestheus to the head his arrow drove,

4509.text:
With lifted eyes, and took his aim above,
But made a glancing shot, and missed the dove;

4516.text:
Yet miss'd so narrow, that he cut the cord
Which fasten'd by the foot the flitting bird.

4521.text:
The captive thus releas'd, away she flies,
And beats with clapping wings the yielding

4528.text:
skies. His bow already bent, Eurytion stood;
And, having first invok'd his brother god,

4536.text:
His winged shaft with eager haste he sped.
The fatal message reach'd her as she fled:

4544.text:
She leaves her life aloft; she strikes the
ground, And renders back the weapon in the

4552.text:
wound. Acestes, grudging at his lot, remains,
Without a prize to gratify his pains. Yet,

4558.text:
shooting upward, sends his shaft, to show
An archer's art, and boast his twanging bow.

4566.text:
The feather'd arrow gave a dire portent, And
latter augurs judge from this event. Chaf'd

4574.text:
by the speed, it fir'd; and, as it flew, A
trail of following flames ascending drew:

4582.text:
Kindling they mount, and mark the shiny way;
Across the skies as falling meteors play,

4588.text:
And vanish into wind, or in a blaze decay.
The Trojans and Sicilians wildly stare, And,

4597.text:
trembling, turn their wonder into pray'r.
The Dardan prince put on a smiling face, And

4604.text:
strain'd Acestes with a close embrace; Then,
hon'ring him with gifts above the rest, Turn'd

4611.text:
the bad omen, nor his fears confess'd. "The
gods," said he, "this miracle have wrought,

4618.text:
And order'd you the prize without the lot.
Accept this goblet, rough with figur'd gold,

4625.text:
Which Thracian Cisseus gave my sire of old:
This pledge of ancient amity receive, Which

4633.text:
to my second sire I justly give." He said,
and, with the trumpets' cheerful sound, Proclaim'd

4642.text:
him victor, and with laurel-crown'd. Nor good
Eurytion envied him the prize, Tho' he transfix'd

4652.text:
the pigeon in the skies. Who cut the line,
with second gifts was grac'd; The third was

4660.text:
his whose arrow pierc'd the mast. The chief,
before the games were wholly done, Call'd

4668.text:
Periphantes, tutor to his son, And whisper'd
thus: "With speed Ascanius find; And, if his

4677.text:
childish troop be ready join'd, On horseback
let him grace his grandsire's day, And lead

4684.text:
his equals arm'd in just array." He said;
and, calling out, the cirque he clears. The

4692.text:
crowd withdrawn, an open plain appears. And
now the noble youths, of form divine, Advance

4700.text:
before their fathers, in a line; The riders
grace the steeds; the steeds with glory shine.

4709.text:
Thus marching on in military pride, Shouts
of applause resound from side to side. Their

4717.text:
casques adorn'd with laurel wreaths they wear,
Each brandishing aloft a cornel spear. Some

4724.text:
at their backs their gilded quivers bore;
Their chains of burnish'd gold hung down before.

4733.text:
Three graceful troops they form'd upon the
green; Three graceful leaders at their head

4739.text:
were seen; Twelve follow'd ev'ry chief, and
left a space between. The first young Priam

4745.text:
led; a lovely boy, Whose grandsire was th'
unhappy king of Troy; His race in after times

4753.text:
was known to fame, New honors adding to the
Latian name; And well the royal boy his Thracian

4761.text:
steed became. White were the fetlocks of his
feet before, And on his front a snowy star

4769.text:
he bore. Then beauteous Atys, with Iulus bred,
Of equal age, the second squadron led. The

4780.text:
last in order, but the first in place, First
in the lovely features of his face, Rode fair

4788.text:
Ascanius on a fiery steed, Queen Dido's gift,
and of the Tyrian breed. Sure coursers for

4797.text:
the rest the king ordains, With golden bits
adorn'd, and purple reins. The pleas'd spectators

4807.text:
peals of shouts renew, And all the parents
in the children view; Their make, their motions,

4816.text:
and their sprightly grace, And hopes and fears
alternate in their face. Th' unfledg'd commanders

4826.text:
and their martial train First make the circuit
of the sandy plain Around their sires, and,

4834.text:
at th' appointed sign, Drawn up in beauteous
order, form a line. The second signal sounds,

4842.text:
the troop divides In three distinguish'd parts,
with three distinguish'd guides Again they

4848.text:
close, and once again disjoin; In troop to
troop oppos'd, and line to line. They meet;

4855.text:
they wheel; they throw their darts afar With
harmless rage and well-dissembled war. Then

4862.text:
in a round the mingled bodies run: Flying
they follow, and pursuing shun; Broken, they

4869.text:
break; and, rallying, they renew In other
forms the military shew. At last, in order,

4877.text:
undiscern'd they join, And march together
in a friendly line. And, as the Cretan labyrinth

4885.text:
of old, With wand'ring ways and many a winding
fold, Involv'd the weary feet, without redress,

4893.text:
In a round error, which denied recess; So
fought the Trojan boys in warlike play, Turn'd

4900.text:
and return'd, and still a diff'rent way. Thus
dolphins in the deep each other chase In circles,

4909.text:
when they swim around the wat'ry race. This
game, these carousels, Ascanius taught; And,

4916.text:
building Alba, to the Latins brought; Shew'd
what he learn'd: the Latin sires impart To

4923.text:
their succeeding sons the graceful art; From
these imperial Rome receiv'd the game, Which

4930.text:
Troy, the youths the Trojan troop, they name.
Thus far the sacred sports they celebrate:

4938.text:
But Fortune soon resum'd her ancient hate;
For, while they pay the dead his annual dues,

4946.text:
Those envied rites Saturnian Juno views; And
sends the goddess of the various bow, To try

4954.text:
new methods of revenge below; Supplies the
winds to wing her airy way, Where in the port

4963.text:
secure the navy lay. Swiftly fair Iris down
her arch descends, And, undiscern'd, her fatal

4975.text:
voyage ends. She saw the gath'ring crowd;
and, gliding thence, The desart shore, and

4983.text:
fleet without defense. The Trojan matrons,
on the sands alone, With sighs and tears Anchises'

4991.text:
death bemoan; Then, turning to the sea their
weeping eyes, Their pity to themselves renews

4999.text:
their cries. "Alas!" said one, "what oceans
yet remain For us to sail! what labors to

5007.text:
sustain!" All take the word, and, with a gen'ral
groan, Implore the gods for peace, and places

5015.text:
of their own. The goddess, great in mischief,
views their pains, And in a woman's form her

5026.text:
heav'nly limbs restrains. In face and shape
old Beroe she became, Doryclus' wife, a venerable

5035.text:
dame, Once blest with riches, and a mother's
name. Thus chang'd, amidst the crying crowd

5042.text:
she ran, Mix'd with the matrons, and these
words began: "O wretched we, whom not the

5050.text:
Grecian pow'r, Nor flames, destroy'd, in Troy's
unhappy hour! O wretched we, reserv'd by cruel

5059.text:
fate, Beyond the ruins of the sinking state!
Now sev'n revolving years are wholly run,

5066.text:
Since this improsp'rous voyage we begun; Since,
toss'd from shores to shores, from lands to

5074.text:
lands, Inhospitable rocks and barren sands,
Wand'ring in exile thro' the stormy sea, We

5081.text:
search in vain for flying Italy. Now cast
by fortune on this kindred land, What should

5089.text:
our rest and rising walls withstand, Or hinder
here to fix our banish'd band? O country lost,

5098.text:
and gods redeem'd in vain, If still in endless
exile we remain! Shall we no more the Trojan

5106.text:
walls renew, Or streams of some dissembled
Simois view! Haste, join with me, th' unhappy

5114.text:
fleet consume! Cassandra bids; and I declare
her doom. In sleep I saw her; she supplied

5123.text:
my hands (For this I more than dreamt) with
flaming brands: 'With these,' said she, 'these

5133.text:
wand'ring ships destroy: These are your fatal
seats, and this your Troy.' Time calls you

5142.text:
now; the precious hour employ: Slack not the
good presage, while Heav'n inspires Our minds

5149.text:
to dare, and gives the ready fires. See! Neptune's
altars minister their brands: The god is pleas'd;

5159.text:
the god supplies our hands." Then from the
pile a flaming fire she drew, And, toss'd

5167.text:
in air, amidst the galleys threw. Wrapp'd
in amaze, the matrons wildly stare: Then Pyrgo,

5176.text:
reverenc'd for her hoary hair, Pyrgo, the
nurse of Priam's num'rous race: "No Beroe

5184.text:
this, tho' she belies her face! What terrors
from her frowning front arise! Behold a goddess

5194.text:
in her ardent eyes! What rays around her heav'nly
face are seen! Mark her majestic voice, and

5203.text:
more than mortal mien! Beroe but now I left,
whom, pin'd with pain, Her age and anguish

5212.text:
from these rites detain," She said. The matrons,
seiz'd with new amaze, Roll their malignant

5219.text:
eyes, and on the navy gaze. They fear, and
hope, and neither part obey: They hope the

5226.text:
fated land, but fear the fatal way. The goddess,
having done her task below, Mounts up on equal

5234.text:
wings, and bends her painted bow. Struck with
the sight, and seiz'd with rage divine, The

5241.text:
matrons prosecute their mad design: They shriek
aloud; they snatch, with impious hands, The

5248.text:
food of altars; fires and flaming brands.
Green boughs and saplings, mingled in their

5256.text:
haste, And smoking torches, on the ships they
cast. The flame, unstopp'd at first, more

5263.text:
fury gains, And Vulcan rides at large with
loosen'd reins: Triumphant to the painted

5271.text:
sterns he soars, And seizes, in this way,
the banks and crackling oars. Eumelus was

5280.text:
the first the news to bear, While yet they
crowd the rural theater. Then, what they hear,

5286.text:
is witness'd by their eyes: A storm of sparkles
and of flames arise. Ascanius took th' alarm,

5294.text:
while yet he led His early warriors on his
prancing steed, And, spurring on, his equals

5302.text:
soon o'erpass'd; Nor could his frighted friends
reclaim his haste. Soon as the royal youth

5310.text:
appear'd in view, He sent his voice before
him as he flew: "What madness moves you, matrons,

5318.text:
to destroy The last remainders of unhappy
Troy! Not hostile fleets, but your own hopes,

5324.text:
you burn, And on your friends your fatal fury
turn. Behold your own Ascanius!" While he

5332.text:
said, He drew his glitt'ring helmet from his
head, In which the youths to sportful arms

5338.text:
he led. By this, Aeneas and his train appear;
And now the women, seiz'd with shame and fear,

5345.text:
Dispers'd, to woods and caverns take their
flight, Abhor their actions, and avoid the

5353.text:
light; Their friends acknowledge, and their
error find, And shake the goddess from their

5358.text:
alter'd mind. Not so the raging fires their
fury cease, But, lurking in the seams, with

5364.text:
seeming peace, Work on their way amid the
smold'ring tow, Sure in destruction, but in

5371.text:
motion slow. The silent plague thro' the green
timber eats, And vomits out a tardy flame

5378.text:
by fits. Down to the keels, and upward to
the sails, The fire descends, or mounts, but

5384.text:
still prevails; Nor buckets pour'd, nor strength
of human hand, Can the victorious element

5391.text:
withstand. The pious hero rends his robe,
and throws To heav'n his hands, and with his

5398.text:
hands his vows. "O Jove," he cried, "if pray'rs
can yet have place; If thou abhorr'st not

5406.text:
all the Dardan race; If any spark of pity
still remain; If gods are gods, and not invok'd

5414.text:
in vain; Yet spare the relics of the Trojan
train! Yet from the flames our burning vessels

5422.text:
free, Or let thy fury fall alone on me! At
this devoted head thy thunder throw, And send
