his trumpet only, but his spear. But by Pelides'
arms when Hector fell, He chose Aeneas; and

7107.text:
he chose as well. Swoln with applause, and
aiming still at more, He now provokes the

7113.text:
sea gods from the shore; With envy Triton
heard the martial sound, And the bold champion,

7119.text:
for his challenge, drown'd; Then cast his
mangled carcass on the strand: The gazing

7124.text:
crowd around the body stand. All weep; but
most Aeneas mourns his fate, And hastens to

7131.text:
perform the funeral state. In altar-wise,
a stately pile they rear; The basis broad

7137.text:
below, and top advanc'd in air. An ancient
wood, fit for the work design'd, (The shady

7142.text:
covert of the salvage kind,) The Trojans found:
the sounding ax is plied; Firs, pines, and

7149.text:
pitch trees, and the tow'ring pride Of forest
ashes, feel the fatal stroke, And piercing

7154.text:
wedges cleave the stubborn oak. Huge trunks
of trees, fell'd from the steepy crown Of

7161.text:
the bare mountains, roll with ruin down. Arm'd
like the rest the Trojan prince appears, And

7167.text:
by his pious labor urges theirs. Thus while
he wrought, revolving in his mind The ways

7173.text:
to compass what his wish design'd, He cast
his eyes upon the gloomy grove, And then with

7179.text:
vows implor'd the Queen of Love: "O may thy
pow'r, propitious still to me, Conduct my

7185.text:
steps to find the fatal tree, In this deep
forest; since the Sibyl's breath Foretold,

7191.text:
alas! too true, Misenus' death." Scarce had
he said, when, full before his sight, Two

7199.text:
doves, descending from their airy flight,
Secure upon the grassy plain alight. He knew

7204.text:
his mother's birds; and thus he pray'd: "Be
you my guides, with your auspicious aid, And

7210.text:
lead my footsteps, till the branch be found,
Whose glitt'ring shadow gilds the sacred ground.

7216.text:
And thou, great parent, with celestial care,
In this distress be present to my pray'r!"

7223.text:
Thus having said, he stopp'd with watchful
sight, Observing still the motions of their

7228.text:
flight, What course they took, what happy
signs they shew. They fed, and, flutt'ring,

7233.text:
by degrees withdrew Still farther from the
place, but still in view: Hopping and flying,

7239.text:
thus they led him on To the slow lake, whose
baleful stench to shun They wing'd their flight

7245.text:
aloft; then, stooping low, Perch'd on the
double tree that bears the golden bough. Thro'

7252.text:
the green leafs the glitt'ring shadows glow;
As, on the sacred oak, the wintry mistletoe,

7257.text:
Where the proud mother views her precious
brood, And happier branches, which she never

7262.text:
sow'd. Such was the glitt'ring; such the ruddy
rind, And dancing leaves, that wanton'd in

7269.text:
the wind. He seiz'd the shining bough with
griping hold, And rent away, with ease, the

7274.text:
ling'ring gold; Then to the Sibyl's palace
bore the prize. Meantime the Trojan troops,

7281.text:
with weeping eyes, To dead Misenus pay his
obsequies. First, from the ground a lofty

7287.text:
pile they rear, Of pitch trees, oaks, and
pines, and unctuous fir: The fabric's front

7292.text:
with cypress twigs they strew, And stick the
sides with boughs of baleful yew. The topmost

7298.text:
part his glitt'ring arms adorn; Warm waters,
then, in brazen caldrons borne, Are pour'd

7304.text:
to wash his body, joint by joint, And fragrant
oils the stiffen'd limbs anoint. With groans

7311.text:
and cries Misenus they deplore: Then on a
bier, with purple cover'd o'er, The breathless

7317.text:
body, thus bewail'd, they lay, And fire the
pile, their faces turn'd away- Such reverend

7323.text:
rites their fathers us'd to pay. Pure oil
and incense on the fire they throw, And fat

7329.text:
of victims, which his friends bestow. These
gifts the greedy flames to dust devour; Then

7335.text:
on the living coals red wine they pour; And,
last, the relics by themselves dispose, Which

7342.text:
in a brazen urn the priests inclose. Old Corynaeus
compass'd thrice the crew, And dipp'd an olive

7349.text:
branch in holy dew; Which thrice he sprinkled
round, and thrice aloud Invok'd the dead,

7355.text:
and then dismissed the crowd. But good Aeneas
order'd on the shore A stately tomb, whose

7361.text:
top a trumpet bore, A soldier's fauchion,
and a seaman's oar. Thus was his friend interr'd;

7368.text:
and deathless fame Still to the lofty cape
consigns his name. These rites perform'd,

7374.text:
the prince, without delay, Hastes to the nether
world his destin'd way. Deep was the cave;

7380.text:
and, downward as it went From the wide mouth,
a rocky rough descent; And here th' access

7385.text:
a gloomy grove defends, And there th' unnavigable
lake extends, O'er whose unhappy waters, void

7392.text:
of light, No bird presumes to steer his airy
flight; Such deadly stenches from the depths

7398.text:
arise, And steaming sulphur, that infects
the skies. From hence the Grecian bards their

7404.text:
legends make, And give the name Avernus to
the lake. Four sable bullocks, in the yoke

7410.text:
untaught, For sacrifice the pious hero brought.
The priestess pours the wine betwixt their

7416.text:
horns; Then cuts the curling hair; that first
oblation burns, Invoking Hecate hither to

7422.text:
repair: A pow'rful name in hell and upper
air. The sacred priests with ready knives

7428.text:
bereave The beasts of life, and in full bowls
receive The streaming blood: a lamb to Hell

7434.text:
and Night (The sable wool without a streak
of white) Aeneas offers; and, by fate's decree,

7440.text:
A barren heifer, Proserpine, to thee, With
holocausts he Pluto's altar fills; Sev'n brawny

7447.text:
bulls with his own hand he kills; Then on
the broiling entrails oil he pours; Which,

7453.text:
ointed thus, the raging flame devours. Late
the nocturnal sacrifice begun, Nor ended till

7460.text:
the next returning sun. Then earth began to
bellow, trees to dance, And howling dogs in

7466.text:
glimm'ring light advance, Ere Hecate came.
"Far hence be souls profane!" The Sibyl cried,

7473.text:
"and from the grove abstain! Now, Trojan,
take the way thy fates afford; Assume thy

7479.text:
courage, and unsheathe thy sword." She said,
and pass'd along the gloomy space; The prince

7486.text:
pursued her steps with equal pace. Ye realms,
yet unreveal'd to human sight, Ye gods who

7492.text:
rule the regions of the night, Ye gliding
ghosts, permit me to relate The mystic wonders

7498.text:
of your silent state! Obscure they went thro'
dreary shades, that led Along the waste dominions

7505.text:
of the dead. Thus wander travelers in woods
by night, By the moon's doubtful and malignant

7512.text:
light, When Jove in dusky clouds involves
the skies, And the faint crescent shoots by

7518.text:
fits before their eyes. Just in the gate and
in the jaws of hell, Revengeful Cares and

7523.text:
sullen Sorrows dwell, And pale Diseases, and
repining Age, Want, Fear, and Famine's unresisted

7531.text:
rage; Here Toils, and Death, and Death's half-brother,
Sleep, Forms terrible to view, their sentry

7538.text:
keep; With anxious Pleasures of a guilty mind,
Deep Frauds before, and open Force behind;

7545.text:
The Furies' iron beds; and Strife, that shakes
Her hissing tresses and unfolds her snakes.

7552.text:
Full in the midst of this infernal road, An
elm displays her dusky arms abroad: The God

7558.text:
of Sleep there hides his heavy head, And empty
dreams on ev'ry leaf are spread. Of various

7565.text:
forms unnumber'd specters more, Centaurs,
and double shapes, besiege the door. Before

7571.text:
the passage, horrid Hydra stands, And Briareus
with all his hundred hands; Gorgons, Geryon

7579.text:
with his triple frame; And vain Chimaera vomits
empty flame. The chief unsheath'd his shining

7586.text:
steel, prepar'd, Tho' seiz'd with sudden fear,
to force the guard, Off'ring his brandish'd

7591.text:
weapon at their face; Had not the Sibyl stopp'd
his eager pace, And told him what those empty

7597.text:
phantoms were: Forms without bodies, and impassive
air. Hence to deep Acheron they take their

7605.text:
way, Whose troubled eddies, thick with ooze
and clay, Are whirl'd aloft, and in Cocytus

7611.text:
lost. There Charon stands, who rules the dreary
coast- A sordid god: down from his hoary chin

7618.text:
A length of beard descends, uncomb'd, unclean;
His eyes, like hollow furnaces on fire; A

7625.text:
girdle, foul with grease, binds his obscene
attire. He spreads his canvas; with his pole

7632.text:
he steers; The freights of flitting ghosts
in his thin bottom bears. He look'd in years;

7638.text:
yet in his years were seen A youthful vigor
and autumnal green. An airy crowd came rushing

7645.text:
where he stood, Which fill'd the margin of
the fatal flood: Husbands and wives, boys

7650.text:
and unmarried maids, And mighty heroes' more
majestic shades, And youths, intomb'd before

7656.text:
their fathers' eyes, With hollow groans, and
shrieks, and feeble cries. Thick as the leaves

7662.text:
in autumn strow the woods, Or fowls, by winter
forc'd, forsake the floods, And wing their

7669.text:
hasty flight to happier lands; Such, and so
thick, the shiv'ring army stands, And press

7675.text:
for passage with extended hands. Now these,
now those, the surly boatman bore: The rest

7682.text:
he drove to distance from the shore. The hero,
who beheld with wond'ring eyes The tumult

7688.text:
mix'd with shrieks, laments, and cries, Ask'd
of his guide, what the rude concourse meant;

7693.text:
Why to the shore the thronging people bent;
What forms of law among the ghosts were us'd;

7699.text:
Why some were ferried o'er, and some refus'd.
"Son of Anchises, offspring of the gods,"

7706.text:
The Sibyl said, "you see the Stygian floods,
The sacred stream which heav'n's imperial

7712.text:
state Attests in oaths, and fears to violate.
The ghosts rejected are th' unhappy crew Depriv'd

7719.text:
of sepulchers and fun'ral due: The boatman,
Charon; those, the buried host, He ferries

7725.text:
over to the farther coast; Nor dares his transport
vessel cross the waves With such whose bones

7732.text:
are not compos'd in graves. A hundred years
they wander on the shore; At length, their

7737.text:
penance done, are wafted o'er." The Trojan
chief his forward pace repress'd, Revolving

7744.text:
anxious thoughts within his breast, He saw
his friends, who, whelm'd beneath the waves,

7749.text:
Their fun'ral honors claim'd, and ask'd their
quiet graves. The lost Leucaspis in the crowd

7755.text:
he knew, And the brave leader of the Lycian
crew, Whom, on the Tyrrhene seas, the tempests

7761.text:
met; The sailors master'd, and the ship o'erset.
Amidst the spirits, Palinurus press'd, Yet

7768.text:
fresh from life, a new-admitted guest, Who,
while he steering view'd the stars, and bore

7773.text:
His course from Afric to the Latian shore,
Fell headlong down. The Trojan fix'd his view,

7780.text:
And scarcely thro' the gloom the sullen shadow
knew. Then thus the prince: "What envious

7786.text:
pow'r, O friend, Brought your lov'd life to
this disastrous end? For Phoebus, ever true

7792.text:
in all he said, Has in your fate alone my
faith betray'd. The god foretold you should

7797.text:
not die, before You reach'd, secure from seas,
th' Italian shore. Is this th' unerring pow'r?"

7804.text:
The ghost replied; "Nor Phoebus flatter'd,
nor his answers lied; Nor envious gods have

7810.text:
sent me to the deep: But, while the stars
and course of heav'n I keep, My wearied eyes

7816.text:
were seiz'd with fatal sleep. I fell; and,
with my weight, the helm constrain'd Was drawn

7822.text:
along, which yet my gripe retain'd. Now by
the winds and raging waves I swear, Your safety,

7828.text:
more than mine, was then my care; Lest, of
the guide bereft, the rudder lost, Your ship

7834.text:
should run against the rocky coast. Three
blust'ring nights, borne by the southern blast,

7839.text:
I floated, and discover'd land at last: High
on a mounting wave my head I bore, Forcing

7845.text:
my strength, and gath'ring to the shore. Panting,
but past the danger, now I seiz'd The craggy

7851.text:
cliffs, and my tir'd members eas'd. While,
cumber'd with my dropping clothes, I lay,

7857.text:
The cruel nation, covetous of prey, Stain'd
with my blood th' unhospitable coast; And

7863.text:
now, by winds and waves, my lifeless limbs
are toss'd: Which O avert, by yon ethereal

7869.text:
light, Which I have lost for this eternal
night! Or, if by dearer ties you may be won,

7875.text:
By your dead sire, and by your living son,
Redeem from this reproach my wand'ring ghost;

7881.text:
Or with your navy seek the Velin coast, And
in a peaceful grave my corpse compose; Or,

7887.text:
if a nearer way your mother shows, Without
whose aid you durst not undertake This frightful

7892.text:
passage o'er the Stygian lake, Lend to this
wretch your hand, and waft him o'er To the

7898.text:
sweet banks of yon forbidden shore." Scarce
had he said, the prophetess began: "What hopes

7905.text:
delude thee, miserable man? Think'st thou,
thus unintomb'd, to cross the floods, To view

7911.text:
the Furies and infernal gods, And visit, without
leave, the dark abodes? Attend the term of

7917.text:
long revolving years; Fate, and the dooming
gods, are deaf to tears. This comfort of thy

7924.text:
dire misfortune take: The wrath of Heav'n,
inflicted for thy sake, With vengeance shall

7930.text:
pursue th' inhuman coast, Till they propitiate
thy offended ghost, And raise a tomb, with

7936.text:
vows and solemn pray'r; And Palinurus' name
the place shall bear." This calm'd his cares;

7943.text:
sooth'd with his future fame, And pleas'd
to hear his propagated name. Now nearer to

7950.text:
the Stygian lake they draw: Whom, from the
shore, the surly boatman saw; Observ'd their

7956.text:
passage thro' the shady wood, And mark'd their
near approaches to the flood. Then thus he

7961.text:
call'd aloud, inflam'd with wrath: "Mortal,
whate'er, who this forbidden path In arms

7967.text:
presum'st to tread, I charge thee, stand,
And tell thy name, and bus'ness in the land.

7974.text:
Know this, the realm of night- the Stygian
shore: My boat conveys no living bodies o'er;

7981.text:
Nor was I pleas'd great Theseus once to bear,
Who forc'd a passage with his pointed spear,

7987.text:
Nor strong Alcides- men of mighty fame, And
from th' immortal gods their lineage came.

7993.text:
In fetters one the barking porter tied, And
took him trembling from his sov'reign's side:

7999.text:
Two sought by force to seize his beauteous
bride." To whom the Sibyl thus: "Compose thy

8006.text:
mind; Nor frauds are here contriv'd, nor force
design'd. Still may the dog the wand'ring

8011.text:
troops constrain Of airy ghosts, and vex the
guilty train, And with her grisly lord his

8017.text:
lovely queen remain. The Trojan chief, whose
lineage is from Jove, Much fam'd for arms,

8023.text:
and more for filial love, Is sent to seek
his sire in your Elysian grove. If neither

8030.text:
piety, nor Heav'n's command, Can gain his
passage to the Stygian strand, This fatal

8036.text:
present shall prevail at least." Then shew'd
the shining bough, conceal'd within her vest.

8042.text:
No more was needful: for the gloomy god Stood
mute with awe, to see the golden rod; Admir'd

8049.text:
the destin'd off'ring to his queen- A venerable
gift, so rarely seen. His fury thus appeas'd,

8056.text:
he puts to land; The ghosts forsake their
seats at his command: He clears the deck,

8061.text:
receives the mighty freight; The leaky vessel
groans beneath the weight. Slowly she sails,

8067.text:
and scarcely stems the tides; The pressing
water pours within her sides. His passengers

8073.text:
at length are wafted o'er, Expos'd, in muddy
weeds, upon the miry shore. No sooner landed,

8081.text:
in his den they found The triple porter of
the Stygian sound, Grim Cerberus, who soon

8087.text:
began to rear His crested snakes, and arm'd
his bristling hair. The prudent Sibyl had

8093.text:
before prepar'd A sop, in honey steep'd, to
charm the guard; Which, mix'd with pow'rful

8099.text:
drugs, she cast before His greedy grinning
jaws, just op'd to roar. With three enormous

8106.text:
mouths he gapes; and straight, With hunger
press'd, devours the pleasing bait. Long draughts

8112.text:
of sleep his monstrous limbs enslave; He reels,
and, falling, fills the spacious cave. The

8119.text:
keeper charm'd, the chief without delay Pass'd
on, and took th' irremeable way. Before the

8126.text:
gates, the cries of babes new born, Whom fate
had from their tender mothers torn, Assault

8132.text:
his ears: then those, whom form of laws Condemn'd
to die, when traitors judg'd their cause.

8139.text:
Nor want they lots, nor judges to review The
wrongful sentence, and award a new. Minos,

8145.text:
the strict inquisitor, appears; And lives
and crimes, with his assessors, hears. Round

8152.text:
in his urn the blended balls he rolls, Absolves
the just, and dooms the guilty souls. The

8158.text:
next, in place and punishment, are they Who
prodigally throw their souls away; Fools,

8164.text:
who, repining at their wretched state, And
loathing anxious life, suborn'd their fate.

8170.text:
With late repentance now they would retrieve
The bodies they forsook, and wish to live;

8175.text:
Their pains and poverty desire to bear, To
view the light of heav'n, and breathe the

8180.text:
vital air: But fate forbids; the Stygian floods
oppose, And with circling streams the captive

8188.text:
souls inclose. End of Book VI, Part I Book
VI, The World Below Part II Not far from thence,

8203.text:
the Mournful Fields appear So call'd from
lovers that inhabit there. The souls whom

8209.text:
that unhappy flame invades, In secret solitude
and myrtle shades Make endless moans, and,

8215.text:
pining with desire, Lament too late their
unextinguish'd fire. Here Procris, Eriphyle

8223.text:
here he found, Baring her breast, yet bleeding
with the wound Made by her son. He saw Pasiphae

8229.text:
there, With Phaedra's ghost, a foul incestuous
pair. There Laodamia, with Evadne, moves,

8237.text:
Unhappy both, but loyal in their loves: Caeneus,
a woman once, and once a man, But ending in

8243.text:
the sex she first began. Not far from these
Phoenician Dido stood, Fresh from her wound,

8251.text:
her bosom bath'd in blood; Whom when the Trojan
hero hardly knew, Obscure in shades, and with

8257.text:
a doubtful view, (Doubtful as he who sees,
thro' dusky night, Or thinks he sees, the

8263.text:
moon's uncertain light,) With tears he first
approach'd the sullen shade; And, as his love

8269.text:
inspir'd him, thus he said: "Unhappy queen!
then is the common breath Of rumor true, in

8275.text:
your reported death, And I, alas! the cause?
By Heav'n, I vow, And all the pow'rs that

8281.text:
rule the realms below, Unwilling I forsook
your friendly state, Commanded by the gods,

8287.text:
and forc'd by fate- Those gods, that fate,
whose unresisted might Have sent me to these

8293.text:
regions void of light, Thro' the vast empire
of eternal night. Nor dar'd I to presume,

8299.text:
that, press'd with grief, My flight should
urge you to this dire relief. Stay, stay your

8305.text:
steps, and listen to my vows: 'T is the last
interview that fate allows!" In vain he thus

8311.text:
attempts her mind to move With tears, and
pray'rs, and late-repenting love. Disdainfully

8317.text:
she look'd; then turning round, But fix'd
her eyes unmov'd upon the ground, And what

8322.text:
he says and swears, regards no more Than the
deaf rocks, when the loud billows roar; But

8328.text:
whirl'd away, to shun his hateful sight, Hid
in the forest and the shades of night; Then

8335.text:
sought Sichaeus thro' the shady grove, Who
answer'd all her cares, and equal'd all her

8340.text:
love. Some pious tears the pitying hero paid,
And follow'd with his eyes the flitting shade,

8346.text:
Then took the forward way, by fate ordain'd,
And, with his guide, the farther fields attain'd,

8353.text:
Where, sever'd from the rest, the warrior
souls remain'd. Tydeus he met, with Meleager's

8358.text:
race, The pride of armies, and the soldiers'
grace; And pale Adrastus with his ghastly

8364.text:
face. Of Trojan chiefs he view'd a num'rous
train, All much lamented, all in battle slain;

8371.text:
Glaucus and Medon, high above the rest, Antenor's
sons, and Ceres' sacred priest. And proud

8378.text:
Idaeus, Priam's charioteer, Who shakes his
empty reins, and aims his airy spear. The

8384.text:
gladsome ghosts, in circling troops, attend
And with unwearied eyes behold their friend;

8390.text:
Delight to hover near, and long to know What
bus'ness brought him to the realms below.

8396.text:
But Argive chiefs, and Agamemnon's train,
When his refulgent arms flash'd thro' the

8401.text:
shady plain, Fled from his well-known face,
with wonted fear, As when his thund'ring sword

8407.text:
and pointed spear Drove headlong to their
ships, and glean'd the routed rear. They rais'd

8412.text:
a feeble cry, with trembling notes; But the
weak voice deceiv'd their gasping throats.

8417.text:
Here Priam's son, Deiphobus, he found, Whose
face and limbs were one continued wound: Dishonest,

8425.text:
with lopp'd arms, the youth appears, Spoil'd
of his nose, and shorten'd of his ears. He

8430.text:
scarcely knew him, striving to disown His
blotted form, and blushing to be known; And

8435.text:
therefore first began: "O Teucer's race, Who
durst thy faultless figure thus deface? What

8442.text:
heart could wish, what hand inflict, this
dire disgrace? 'Twas fam'd, that in our last

8447.text:
and fatal night Your single prowess long sustain'd
the fight, Till tir'd, not forc'd, a glorious

8453.text:
fate you chose, And fell upon a heap of slaughter'd
foes. But, in remembrance of so brave a deed,

8460.text:
A tomb and fun'ral honors I decreed; Thrice
call'd your manes on the Trojan plains: The

8466.text:
place your armor and your name retains. Your
body too I sought, and, had I found, Design'd

8471.text:
for burial in your native ground." The ghost
replied: "Your piety has paid All needful

8478.text:
rites, to rest my wand'ring shade; But cruel
fate, and my more cruel wife, To Grecian swords

8485.text:
betray'd my sleeping life. These are the monuments
of Helen's love: The shame I bear below, the

8492.text:
marks I bore above. You know in what deluding
joys we pass'd The night that was by Heav'n

8497.text:
decreed our last: For, when the fatal horse,
descending down, Pregnant with arms, o'erwhelm'd

8503.text:
th' unhappy town She feign'd nocturnal orgies;
left my bed, And, mix'd with Trojan dames,

8509.text:
the dances led Then, waving high her torch,
the signal made, Which rous'd the Grecians

8515.text:
from their ambuscade. With watching overworn,
with cares oppress'd, Unhappy I had laid me

8520.text:
down to rest, And heavy sleep my weary limbs
possess'd. Meantime my worthy wife our arms

8527.text:
mislaid, And from beneath my head my sword
convey'd; The door unlatch'd, and, with repeated

8533.text:
calls, Invites her former lord within my walls.
Thus in her crime her confidence she plac'd,

8539.text:
And with new treasons would redeem the past.
What need I more? Into the room they ran,

8545.text:
And meanly murther'd a defenseless man. Ulysses,
basely born, first led the way. Avenging pow'rs!

8553.text:
with justice if I pray, That fortune be their
own another day! But answer you; and in your

8559.text:
turn relate, What brought you, living, to
the Stygian state: Driv'n by the winds and

8563.text:
errors of the sea, Or did you Heav'n's superior
doom obey? Or tell what other chance conducts

8569.text:
your way, To view with mortal eyes our dark
retreats, Tumults and torments of th' infernal

8575.text:
seats." While thus in talk the flying hours
they pass, The sun had finish'd more than

8581.text:
half his race: And they, perhaps, in words
and tears had spent The little time of stay

8586.text:
which Heav'n had lent; But thus the Sibyl
chides their long delay: "Night rushes down,

8592.text:
and headlong drives the day: 'T is here, in
different paths, the way divides; The right

8597.text:
to Pluto's golden palace guides; The left
to that unhappy region tends, Which to the

8602.text:
depth of Tartarus descends; The seat of night
profound, and punish'd fiends." Then thus

8610.text:
Deiphobus: "O sacred maid, Forbear to chide,
and be your will obey'd! Lo! to the secret

8615.text:
shadows I retire, To pay my penance till my
years expire. Proceed, auspicious prince,

8621.text:
with glory crown'd, And born to better fates
than I have found." He said; and, while he

8628.text:
said, his steps he turn'd To secret shadows,
and in silence mourn'd. The hero, looking

8634.text:
on the left, espied A lofty tow'r, and strong
on ev'ry side With treble walls, which Phlegethon

8640.text:
surrounds, Whose fiery flood the burning empire
bounds; And, press'd betwixt the rocks, the

8646.text:
bellowing noise resounds Wide is the fronting
gate, and, rais'd on high With adamantine

8652.text:
columns, threats the sky. Vain is the force
of man, and Heav'n's as vain, To crush the

8657.text:
pillars which the pile sustain. Sublime on
these a tow'r of steel is rear'd; And dire

8663.text:
Tisiphone there keeps the ward, Girt in her
sanguine gown, by night and day, Observant

8669.text:
of the souls that pass the downward way. From
hence are heard the groans of ghosts, the

8675.text:
pains Of sounding lashes and of dragging chains.
The Trojan stood astonish'd at their cries,

8681.text:
And ask'd his guide from whence those yells
arise; And what the crimes, and what the tortures

8686.text:
were, And loud laments that rent the liquid
air. She thus replied: "The chaste and holy

8694.text:
race Are all forbidden this polluted place.
But Hecate, when she gave to rule the woods,

8700.text:
Then led me trembling thro' these dire abodes,
And taught the tortures of th' avenging gods.

8706.text:
These are the realms of unrelenting fate;
And awful Rhadamanthus rules the state. He

8712.text:
hears and judges each committed crime; Enquires
into the manner, place, and time. The conscious

8718.text:
wretch must all his acts reveal, (Loth to
confess, unable to conceal), From the first

8724.text:
moment of his vital breath, To his last hour
of unrepenting death. Straight, o'er the guilty

8731.text:
ghost, the Fury shakes The sounding whip and
brandishes her snakes, And the pale sinner,

8736.text:
with her sisters, takes. Then, of itself,
unfolds th' eternal door; With dreadful sounds

8742.text:
the brazen hinges roar. You see, before the
gate, what stalking ghost Commands the guard,

8748.text:
what sentries keep the post. More formidable
Hydra stands within, Whose jaws with iron

8754.text:
teeth severely grin. The gaping gulf low to
the center lies, And twice as deep as earth

8760.text:
is distant from the skies. The rivals of the
gods, the Titan race, Here, sing'd with lightning,

8767.text:
roll within th' unfathom'd space. Here lie
th' Alaean twins, (I saw them both,) Enormous

8774.text:
bodies, of gigantic growth, Who dar'd in fight
the Thund'rer to defy, Affect his heav'n,

8780.text:
and force him from the sky. Salmoneus, suff'ring
cruel pains, I found, For emulating Jove;

8786.text:
the rattling sound Of mimic thunder, and the
glitt'ring blaze Of pointed lightnings, and

8791.text:
their forky rays. Thro' Elis and the Grecian
towns he flew; Th' audacious wretch four fiery

8798.text:
coursers drew: He wav'd a torch aloft, and,
madly vain, Sought godlike worship from a

8804.text:
servile train. Ambitious fool! with horny
hoofs to pass O'er hollow arches of resounding

8810.text:
brass, To rival thunder in its rapid course,
And imitate inimitable force! But he, the

8817.text:
King of Heav'n, obscure on high, Bar'd his
red arm, and, launching from the sky His writhen

8823.text:
bolt, not shaking empty smoke, Down to the
deep abyss the flaming felon strook. There

8829.text:
Tityus was to see, who took his birth From
heav'n, his nursing from the foodful earth.

8835.text:
Here his gigantic limbs, with large embrace,
Infold nine acres of infernal space. A rav'nous

8842.text:
vulture, in his open'd side, Her crooked beak
and cruel talons tried; Still for the growing

8848.text:
liver digg'd his breast; The growing liver
still supplied the feast; Still are his entrails

8854.text:
fruitful to their pains: Th' immortal hunger
lasts, th' immortal food remains. Ixion and

8861.text:
Perithous I could name, And more Thessalian
chiefs of mighty fame. High o'er their heads

8867.text:
a mold'ring rock is plac'd, That promises
a fall, and shakes at ev'ry blast. They lie

8873.text:
below, on golden beds display'd; And genial
feasts with regal pomp are made. The Queen

8879.text:
of Furies by their sides is set, And snatches
from their mouths th' untasted meat, Which

8885.text:
if they touch, her hissing snakes she rears,
Tossing her torch, and thund'ring in their

8890.text:
ears. Then they, who brothers' better claim
disown, Expel their parents, and usurp the

8895.text:
throne; Defraud their clients, and, to lucre
sold, Sit brooding on unprofitable gold; Who

8902.text:
dare not give, and ev'n refuse to lend To
their poor kindred, or a wanting friend. Vast

8908.text:
is the throng of these; nor less the train
Of lustful youths, for foul adult'ry slain:

8915.text:
Hosts of deserters, who their honor sold,
And basely broke their faith for bribes of

8920.text:
gold. All these within the dungeon's depth
remain, Despairing pardon, and expecting pain.

8927.text:
Ask not what pains; nor farther seek to know
Their process, or the forms of law below.

8933.text:
Some roll a weighty stone; some, laid along,
And bound with burning wires, on spokes of

8938.text:
wheels are hung Unhappy Theseus, doom'd for
ever there, Is fix'd by fate on his eternal

8945.text:
chair; And wretched Phlegyas warns the world
with cries (Could warning make the world more

8951.text:
just or wise): 'Learn righteousness, and dread
th' avenging deities.' To tyrants others have

8957.text:
their country sold, Imposing foreign lords,
for foreign gold; Some have old laws repeal'd,

8963.text:
new statutes made, Not as the people pleas'd,
but as they paid; With incest some their daughters'

8969.text:
bed profan'd: All dar'd the worst of ills,
and, what they dar'd, attain'd. Had I a hundred

8977.text:
mouths, a hundred tongues, And throats of
brass, inspir'd with iron lungs, I could not

8982.text:
half those horrid crimes repeat, Nor half
the punishments those crimes have met. But

8987.text:
let us haste our voyage to pursue: The walls
of Pluto's palace are in view; The gate, and

8993.text:
iron arch above it, stands On anvils labor'd
by the Cyclops' hands. Before our farther

8999.text:
way the Fates allow, Here must we fix on high
the golden bough." She said: and thro' the

9006.text:
gloomy shades they pass'd, And chose the middle
path. Arriv'd at last, The prince with living

9011.text:
water sprinkled o'er His limbs and body; then
approach'd the door, Possess'd the porch,

9018.text:
and on the front above He fix'd the fatal
bough requir'd by Pluto's love. These holy

9024.text:
rites perform'd, they took their way Where
long extended plains of pleasure lay: The

9029.text:
verdant fields with those of heav'n may vie,
With ether vested, and a purple sky; The blissful

9035.text:
seats of happy souls below. Stars of their
own, and their own suns, they know; Their

9041.text:
airy limbs in sports they exercise, And on
the green contend the wrestler's prize. Some

9047.text:
in heroic verse divinely sing; Others in artful
measures led the ring. The Thracian bard,

9054.text:
surrounded by the rest, There stands conspicuous
in his flowing vest; His flying fingers, and

9060.text:
harmonious quill, Strikes sev'n distinguish'd
notes, and sev'n at once they fill. Here found

9066.text:
they Teucer's old heroic race, Born better
times and happier years to grace. Assaracus

9072.text:
and Ilus here enjoy Perpetual fame, with him
who founded Troy. The chief beheld their chariots

9079.text:
from afar, Their shining arms, and coursers
train'd to war: Their lances fix'd in earth,

9085.text:
their steeds around, Free from their harness,
graze the flow'ry ground. The love of horses

9091.text:
which they had, alive, And care of chariots,
after death survive. Some cheerful souls were

9097.text:
feasting on the plain; Some did the song,
and some the choir maintain, Beneath a laurel

9103.text:
shade, where mighty Po Mounts up to woods
above, and hides his head below. Here patriots

9110.text:
live, who, for their country's good, In fighting
fields, were prodigal of blood: Priests of

9116.text:
unblemish'd lives here make abode, And poets
worthy their inspiring god; And searching

9122.text:
wits, of more mechanic parts, Who grac'd their
age with new-invented arts: Those who to worth

9128.text:
their bounty did extend, And those who knew
that bounty to commend. The heads of these

9133.text:
with holy fillets bound, And all their temples
were with garlands crown'd. To these the Sibyl

9140.text:
thus her speech address'd, And first to him
surrounded by the rest (Tow'ring his height,

9146.text:
and ample was his breast): "Say, happy souls,
divine Musaeus, say, Where lives Anchises,

9152.text:
and where lies our way To find the hero, for
whose only sake We sought the dark abodes,

9159.text:
and cross'd the bitter lake?" To this the
sacred poet thus replied: "In no fix'd place

9165.text:
the happy souls reside. In groves we live,
and lie on mossy beds, By crystal streams,

9172.text:
that murmur thro' the meads: But pass yon
easy hill, and thence descend; The path conducts

9178.text:
you to your journey's end." This said, he
led them up the mountain's brow, And shews

9184.text:
them all the shining fields below. They wind
the hill, and thro' the blissful meadows go.

9190.text:
But old Anchises, in a flow'ry vale, Review'd
his muster'd race, and took the tale: Those

9196.text:
happy spirits, which, ordain'd by fate, For
future beings and new bodies wait- With studious

9202.text:
thought observ'd th' illustrious throng, In
nature's order as they pass'd along: Their

9208.text:
names, their fates, their conduct, and their
care, In peaceful senates and successful war.

9214.text:
He, when Aeneas on the plain appears, Meets
him with open arms, and falling tears. "Welcome,"

9221.text:
he said, "the gods' undoubted race! O long
expected to my dear embrace! Once more 't

9231.text:
is giv'n me to behold your face! The love
and pious duty which you pay Have pass'd the

9237.text:
perils of so hard a way. 'T is true, computing
times, I now believ'd The happy day approach'd;

9244.text:
nor are my hopes deceiv'd. What length of
lands, what oceans have you pass'd; What storms

9250.text:
sustain'd, and on what shores been cast? How
have I fear'd your fate! but fear'd it most,

9256.text:
When love assail'd you, on the Libyan coast."
To this, the filial duty thus replies: "Your

9264.text:
sacred ghost before my sleeping eyes Appear'd,
and often urg'd this painful enterprise. After

9270.text:
long tossing on the Tyrrhene sea, My navy
rides at anchor in the bay. But reach your

9275.text:
hand, O parent shade, nor shun The dear embraces
of your longing son!" He said; and falling

9281.text:
tears his face bedew: Then thrice around his
neck his arms he threw; And thrice the flitting

9286.text:
shadow slipp'd away, Like winds, or empty
dreams that fly the day. Now, in a secret

9293.text:
vale, the Trojan sees A sep'rate grove, thro'
which a gentle breeze Plays with a passing

9298.text:
breath, and whispers thro' the trees; And,
just before the confines of the wood, The

9303.text:
gliding Lethe leads her silent flood. About
the boughs an airy nation flew, Thick as the

9310.text:
humming bees, that hunt the golden dew; In
summer's heat on tops of lilies feed, And

9315.text:
creep within their bells, to suck the balmy
seed: The winged army roams the fields around;

9321.text:
The rivers and the rocks remurmur to the sound.
Aeneas wond'ring stood, then ask'd the cause

9327.text:
Which to the stream the crowding people draws.
Then thus the sire: "The souls that throng

9333.text:
the flood Are those to whom, by fate, are
other bodies ow'd: In Lethe's lake they long

9339.text:
oblivion taste, Of future life secure, forgetful
of the past. Long has my soul desir'd this

9346.text:
time and place, To set before your sight your
glorious race, That this presaging joy may

9352.text:
fire your mind To seek the shores by destiny
design'd."- "O father, can it be, that souls

9359.text:
sublime Return to visit our terrestrial clime,
And that the gen'rous mind, releas'd by death,

9366.text:
Can covet lazy limbs and mortal breath?" Anchises
then, in order, thus begun To clear those

9372.text:
wonders to his godlike son: "Know, first,
that heav'n, and earth's compacted frame,

9378.text:
And flowing waters, and the starry flame,
And both the radiant lights, one common soul

9384.text:
Inspires and feeds, and animates the whole.
This active mind, infus'd thro' all the space,

9391.text:
Unites and mingles with the mighty mass. Hence
men and beasts the breath of life obtain,

9397.text:
And birds of air, and monsters of the main.
Th' ethereal vigor is in all the same, And

9403.text:
every soul is fill'd with equal flame; As
much as earthy limbs, and gross allay Of mortal

9409.text:
members, subject to decay, Blunt not the beams
of heav'n and edge of day. From this coarse

9415.text:
mixture of terrestrial parts, Desire and fear
by turns possess their hearts, And grief,

9421.text:
and joy; nor can the groveling mind, In the
dark dungeon of the limbs confin'd, Assert

9426.text:
the native skies, or own its heav'nly kind:
Nor death itself can wholly wash their stains;

9432.text:
But long-contracted filth ev'n in the soul
remains. The relics of inveterate vice they

9438.text:
wear, And spots of sin obscene in ev'ry face
appear. For this are various penances enjoin'd;

9445.text:
And some are hung to bleach upon the wind,
Some plung'd in waters, others purg'd in fires,

9451.text:
Till all the dregs are drain'd, and all the
rust expires. All have their manes, and those

9457.text:
manes bear: The few, so cleans'd, to these
abodes repair, And breathe, in ample fields,

9463.text:
the soft Elysian air. Then are they happy,
when by length of time The scurf is worn away

9470.text:
of each committed crime; No speck is left
of their habitual stains, But the pure ether

9475.text:
of the soul remains. But, when a thousand
rolling years are past, (So long their punishments

9482.text:
and penance last,) Whole droves of minds are,
by the driving god, Compell'd to drink the

9487.text:
deep Lethaean flood, In large forgetful draughts
to steep the cares Of their past labors, and

9494.text:
their irksome years, That, unrememb'ring of
its former pain, The soul may suffer mortal

9500.text:
flesh again." Thus having said, the father
spirit leads The priestess and his son thro'

9508.text:
swarms of shades, And takes a rising ground,
from thence to see The long procession of

9513.text:
his progeny. "Survey," pursued the sire, "this
airy throng, As, offer'd to thy view, they

9520.text:
pass along. These are th' Italian names, which
fate will join With ours, and graff upon the

9526.text:
Trojan line. Observe the youth who first appears
in sight, And holds the nearest station to

9531.text:
the light, Already seems to snuff the vital
air, And leans just forward, on a shining

9538.text:
spear: Silvius is he, thy last-begotten race,
But first in order sent, to fill thy place;

9544.text:
An Alban name, but mix'd with Dardan blood,
Born in the covert of a shady wood: Him fair

9551.text:
Lavinia, thy surviving wife, Shall breed in
groves, to lead a solitary life. In Alba he

9558.text:
shall fix his royal seat, And, born a king,
a race of kings beget. Then Procas, honor

9564.text:
of the Trojan name, Capys, and Numitor, of
endless fame. A second Silvius after these

9570.text:
appears; Silvius Aeneas, for thy name he bears;
For arms and justice equally renown'd, Who,

9577.text:
late restor'd, in Alba shall be crown'd. How
great they look! how vig'rously they wield

9584.text:
Their weighty lances, and sustain the shield!
But they, who crown'd with oaken wreaths appear,

9590.text:
Shall Gabian walls and strong Fidena rear;
Nomentum, Bola, with Pometia, found; And raise

9596.text:
Collatian tow'rs on rocky ground. All these
shall then be towns of mighty fame, Tho' now

9603.text:
they lie obscure, and lands without a name.
See Romulus the great, born to restore The

9609.text:
crown that once his injur'd grandsire wore.
This prince a priestess of your blood shall

9615.text:
bear, And like his sire in arms he shall appear.
Two rising crests, his royal head adorn; Born

9622.text:
from a god, himself to godhead born: His sire
already signs him for the skies, And marks

9628.text:
the seat amidst the deities. Auspicious chief!
thy race, in times to come, Shall spread the

9634.text:
conquests of imperial Rome- Rome, whose ascending
tow'rs shall heav'n invade, Involving earth

9640.text:
and ocean in her shade; High as the Mother
of the Gods in place, And proud, like her,

9646.text:
of an immortal race. Then, when in pomp she
makes the Phrygian round, With golden turrets

9652.text:
on her temples crown'd; A hundred gods her
sweeping train supply; Her offspring all,

9658.text:
and all command the sky. "Now fix your sight,
and stand intent, to see Your Roman race,

9665.text:
and Julian progeny. The mighty Caesar waits
his vital hour, Impatient for the world, and

9672.text:
grasps his promis'd pow'r. But next behold
the youth of form divine, Ceasar himself,

9678.text:
exalted in his line; Augustus, promis'd oft,
and long foretold, Sent to the realm that

9684.text:
Saturn rul'd of old; Born to restore a better
age of gold. Afric and India shall his pow'r

9692.text:
obey; He shall extend his propagated sway
Beyond the solar year, without the starry

9697.text:
way, Where Atlas turns the rolling heav'ns
around, And his broad shoulders with their

9702.text:
lights are crown'd. At his foreseen approach,
already quake The Caspian kingdoms and Maeotian

9709.text:
lake: Their seers behold the tempest from
afar, And threat'ning oracles denounce the

9715.text:
war. Nile hears him knocking at his sev'nfold
gates, And seeks his hidden spring, and fears

9721.text:
his nephew's fates. Nor Hercules more lands
or labors knew, Not tho' the brazen-footed

9727.text:
hind he slew, Freed Erymanthus from the foaming
boar, And dipp'd his arrows in Lernaean gore;

9735.text:
Nor Bacchus, turning from his Indian war,
By tigers drawn triumphant in his car, From

9740.text:
Nisus' top descending on the plains, With
curling vines around his purple reins. And

9746.text:
doubt we yet thro' dangers to pursue The paths
of honor, and a crown in view? But what's

9752.text:
the man, who from afar appears? His head with
olive crown'd, his hand a censer bears, His

9759.text:
hoary beard and holy vestments bring His lost
idea back: I know the Roman king. He shall

9765.text:
to peaceful Rome new laws ordain, Call'd from
his mean abode a scepter to sustain. Him Tullus

9772.text:
next in dignity succeeds, An active prince,
and prone to martial deeds. He shall his troops

9779.text:
for fighting fields prepare, Disus'd to toils,
and triumphs of the war. By dint of sword

9786.text:
his crown he shall increase, And scour his
armor from the rust of peace. Whom Ancus follows,

9793.text:
with a fawning air, But vain within, and proudly
popular. Next view the Tarquin kings, th'

9800.text:
avenging sword Of Brutus, justly drawn, and
Rome restor'd. He first renews the rods and

9806.text:
ax severe, And gives the consuls royal robes
to wear. His sons, who seek the tyrant to

9812.text:
sustain, And long for arbitrary lords again,
With ignominy scourg'd, in open sight, He

9819.text:
dooms to death deserv'd, asserting public
right. Unhappy man, to break the pious laws

9825.text:
Of nature, pleading in his children's cause!
Howeer the doubtful fact is understood, 'T

9831.text:
is love of honor, and his country's good:
The consul, not the father, sheds the blood.

9838.text:
Behold Torquatus the same track pursue; And,
next, the two devoted Decii view: The Drusian

9844.text:
line, Camillus loaded home With standards
well redeem'd, and foreign foes o'ercome The

9850.text:
pair you see in equal armor shine, Now, friends
below, in close embraces join; But, when they

9857.text:
leave the shady realms of night, And, cloth'd
in bodies, breathe your upper light, With

9862.text:
mortal hate each other shall pursue: What
wars, what wounds, what slaughter shall ensue!

9868.text:
From Alpine heights the father first descends;
His daughter's husband in the plain attends:

9873.text:
His daughter's husband arms his eastern friends.
Embrace again, my sons, be foes no more; Nor

9880.text:
stain your country with her children's gore!
And thou, the first, lay down thy lawless

9886.text:
claim, Thou, of my blood, who bearist the
Julian name! Another comes, who shall in triumph

9892.text:
ride, And to the Capitol his chariot guide,
From conquer'd Corinth, rich with Grecian

9898.text:
spoils. And yet another, fam'd for warlike
toils, On Argos shall impose the Roman laws,

9905.text:
And on the Greeks revenge the Trojan cause;
Shall drag in chains their Achillean race;

9910.text:
Shall vindicate his ancestors' disgrace, And
Pallas, for her violated place. Great Cato

9917.text:
there, for gravity renown'd, And conqu'ring
Cossus goes with laurels crown'd. Who can

9923.text:
omit the Gracchi? who declare The Scipios'
worth, those thunderbolts of war, The double

9929.text:
bane of Carthage? Who can see Without esteem
for virtuous poverty, Severe Fabricius, or

9936.text:
can cease t' admire The plowman consul in
his coarse attire? Tir'd as I am, my praise

9942.text:
the Fabii claim; And thou, great hero, greatest
of thy name, Ordain'd in war to save the sinking

9949.text:
state, And, by delays, to put a stop to fate!
Let others better mold the running mass Of

9956.text:
metals, and inform the breathing brass, And
soften into flesh a marble face; Plead better

9962.text:
at the bar; describe the skies, And when the
stars descend, and when they rise. But, Rome,

9967.text:
't is thine alone, with awful sway, To rule
mankind, and make the world obey, Disposing

9974.text:
peace and war by thy own majestic way; To
tame the proud, the fetter'd slave to free:

9981.text:
These are imperial arts, and worthy thee."
He paus'd; and, while with wond'ring eyes

9987.text:
they view'd The passing spirits, thus his
speech renew'd: "See great Marcellus! how,

9994.text:
untir'd in toils, He moves with manly grace,
how rich with regal spoils! He, when his country,

10001.text:
threaten'd with alarms, Requires his courage
and his conqu'ring arms, Shall more than once

10006.text:
the Punic bands affright; Shall kill the Gaulish
king in single fight; Then to the Capitol

10012.text:
in triumph move, And the third spoils shall
grace Feretrian Jove." Aeneas here beheld,

10019.text:
of form divine, A godlike youth in glitt'ring
armor shine, With great Marcellus keeping

10024.text:
equal pace; But gloomy were his eyes, dejected
was his face. He saw, and, wond'ring, ask'd

10031.text:
his airy guide, What and of whence was he,
who press'd the hero's side: "His son, or

10037.text:
one of his illustrious name? How like the
former, and almost the same! Observe the crowds

10043.text:
that compass him around; All gaze, and all
admire, and raise a shouting sound: But hov'ring

10049.text:
mists around his brows are spread, And night,
with sable shades, involves his head."

10055.text:
"Seek not to know," the ghost replied with
tears, "The sorrows of thy sons in future

10061.text:
years. This youth (the blissful vision of
a day) Shall just be shown on earth, and snatch'd

10068.text:
away. The gods too high had rais'd the Roman
state, Were but their gifts as permanent as

10074.text:
great. What groans of men shall fill the Martian
field! How fierce a blaze his flaming pile

10080.text:
shall yield! What fun'ral pomp shall floating
Tiber see, When, rising from his bed, he views

10086.text:
the sad solemnity! No youth shall equal hopes
of glory give, No youth afford so great a

10092.text:
cause to grieve; The Trojan honor, and the
Roman boast, Admir'd when living, and ador'd

10098.text:
when lost! Mirror of ancient faith in early
youth! Undaunted worth, inviolable truth!

10105.text:
No foe, unpunish'd, in the fighting field
Shall dare thee, foot to foot, with sword

10110.text:
and shield; Much less in arms oppose thy matchless
force, When thy sharp spurs shall urge thy

10116.text:
foaming horse. Ah! couldst thou break thro'
fate's severe decree, A new Marcellus shall

10123.text:
arise in thee! Full canisters of fragrant
lilies bring, Mix'd with the purple roses

10128.text:
of the spring; Let me with fun'ral flow'rs
his body strow; This gift which parents to

10134.text:
their children owe, This unavailing gift,
at least, I may bestow!" Thus having said,

10142.text:
he led the hero round The confines of the
blest Elysian ground; Which when Anchises

10147.text:
to his son had shown, And fir'd his mind to
mount the promis'd throne, He tells the future

10154.text:
wars, ordain'd by fate; The strength and customs
of the Latian state; The prince, and people;

10160.text:
and forearms his care With rules, to push
his fortune, or to bear. Two gates the silent

10166.text:
house of Sleep adorn; Of polish'd ivory this,
that of transparent horn: True visions thro'

10173.text:
transparent horn arise; Thro' polish'd ivory
pass deluding lies. Of various things discoursing

10180.text:
as he pass'd, Anchises hither bends his steps
at last. Then, thro' the gate of iv'ry, he

10187.text:
dismiss'd His valiant offspring and divining
guest. Straight to the ships Aeneas his way,

10194.text:
Embark'd his men, and skimm'd along the sea,
Still coasting, till he gain'd Cajeta's bay.

10201.text:
At length on oozy ground his galleys moor;
Their heads are turn'd to sea, their sterns

10207.text:
to shore. End of Book VI Book VII, Juno Served
by a Fury Part I And thou, O matron of immortal

10222.text:
fame, Here dying, to the shore hast left thy
name; Cajeta still the place is call'd from

10230.text:
thee, The nurse of great Aeneas' infancy.
Here rest thy bones in rich Hesperia's plains;

10239.text:
Thy name ('t is all a ghost can have) remains.
Now, when the prince her fun'ral rites had

10251.text:
paid, He plow'd the Tyrrhene seas with sails
display'd. From land a gentle breeze arose

10258.text:
by night, Serenely shone the stars, the moon
was bright, And the sea trembled with her

10266.text:
silver light. Now near the shelves of Circe's
shores they run, (Circe the rich, the daughter

10275.text:
of the Sun,) A dang'rous coast: the goddess
wastes her days In joyous songs; the rocks

10282.text:
resound her lays: In spinning, or the loom,
she spends the night, And cedar brands supply

10290.text:
her father's light. From hence were heard,
rebellowing to the main, The roars of lions

10297.text:
that refuse the chain, The grunts of bristled
boars, and groans of bears, And herds of howling

10305.text:
wolves that stun the sailors' ears. These
from their caverns, at the close of night,

10311.text:
Fill the sad isle with horror and affright.
Darkling they mourn their fate, whom Circe's

10319.text:
pow'r, (That watch'd the moon and planetary
hour,) With words and wicked herbs from humankind

10326.text:
Had alter'd, and in brutal shapes confin'd.
Which monsters lest the Trojans' pious host

10334.text:
Should bear, or touch upon th' inchanted coast,
Propitious Neptune steer'd their course by

10341.text:
night With rising gales that sped their happy
flight. Supplied with these, they skim the

10349.text:
sounding shore, And hear the swelling surges
vainly roar. Now, when the rosy morn began

10357.text:
to rise, And wav'd her saffron streamer thro'
the skies; When Thetis blush'd in purple not

10364.text:
her own, And from her face the breathing winds
were blown, A sudden silence sate upon the

10372.text:
sea, And sweeping oars, with struggling, urge
their way. The Trojan, from the main, beheld

10380.text:
a wood, Which thick with shades and a brown
horror stood: Betwixt the trees the Tiber

10388.text:
took his course, With whirlpools dimpled;
and with downward force, That drove the sand

10394.text:
along, he took his way, And roll'd his yellow
billows to the sea. About him, and above,

10403.text:
and round the wood, The birds that haunt the
borders of his flood, That bath'd within,

10409.text:
or basked upon his side, To tuneful songs
their narrow throats applied. The captain

10417.text:
gives command; the joyful train Glide thro'
the gloomy shade, and leave the main. Now,

10425.text:
Erato, thy poet's mind inspire, And fill his
soul with thy celestial fire! Relate what

10435.text:
Latium was; her ancient kings; Declare the
past and state of things, When first the Trojan

10444.text:
fleet Ausonia sought, And how the rivals lov'd,
and how they fought. These are my theme, and

10453.text:
how the war began, And how concluded by the
godlike man: For I shall sing of battles,

10461.text:
blood, and rage, Which princes and their people
did engage; And haughty souls, that, mov'd

10470.text:
with mutual hate, In fighting fields pursued
and found their fate; That rous'd the Tyrrhene

10478.text:
realm with loud alarms, And peaceful Italy
involv'd in arms. A larger scene of action

10486.text:
is display'd; And, rising hence, a greater
work is weigh'd. Latinus, old and mild, had

10496.text:
long possess'd The Latin scepter, and his
people blest: His father Faunus; a Laurentian

10506.text:
dame His mother; fair Marica was her name.
But Faunus came from Picus: Picus drew His

10514.text:
birth from Saturn, if records be true. Thus
King Latinus, in the third degree, Had Saturn

10522.text:
author of his family. But this old peaceful
prince, as Heav'n decreed, Was blest with

10530.text:
no male issue to succeed: His sons in blooming
youth were snatch'd by fate; One only daughter

10539.text:
heir'd the royal state. Fir'd with her love,
and with ambition led, The neighb'ring princes

10547.text:
court her nuptial bed. Among the crowd, but
far above the rest, Young Turnus to the beauteous

10555.text:
maid address'd. Turnus, for high descent and
graceful mien, Was first, and favor'd by the

10563.text:
Latian queen; With him she strove to join
Lavinia's hand, But dire portents the purpos'd

10571.text:
match withstand. Deep in the palace, of long
growth, there stood A laurel's trunk, a venerable

10581.text:
wood; Where rites divine were paid; whose
holy hair Was kept and cut with superstitious

10588.text:
care. This plant Latinus, when his town he
wall'd, Then found, and from the tree Laurentum

10597.text:
call'd; And last, in honor of his new abode,
He vow'd the laurel to the laurel's god. It

10607.text:
happen'd once (a boding prodigy!) A swarm
of bees, that cut the liquid sky, (Unknown

10615.text:
from whence they took their airy flight,)
Upon the topmost branch in clouds alight;

10621.text:
There with their clasping feet together clung,
And a long cluster from the laurel hung. An

10629.text:
ancient augur prophesied from hence: "Behold
on Latian shores a foreign prince! From the

10639.text:
same parts of heav'n his navy stands, To the
same parts on earth; his army lands; The town

10647.text:
he conquers, and the tow'r commands." Yet
more, when fair Lavinia fed the fire Before

10655.text:
the gods, and stood beside her sire, (Strange
to relate!) the flames, involv'd in smoke

10662.text:
Of incense, from the sacred altar broke, Caught
her dishevel'd hair and rich attire; Her crown

10669.text:
and jewels crackled in the fire: From thence
the fuming trail began to spread And lambent

10676.text:
glories danc'd about her head. This new portent
the seer with wonder views, Then pausing,

10685.text:
thus his prophecy renews: "The nymph, who
scatters flaming fires around, Shall shine

10692.text:
with honor, shall herself be crown'd; But,
caus'd by her irrevocable fate, War shall

10700.text:
the country waste, and change the state."
Latinus, frighted with this dire ostent, For

10708.text:
counsel to his father Faunus went, And sought
the shades renown'd for prophecy Which near

10715.text:
Albunea's sulph'rous fountain lie. To these
the Latian and the Sabine land Fly, when distress'd,

10725.text:
and thence relief demand. The priest on skins
of off'rings takes his ease, And nightly visions

10733.text:
in his slumber sees; A swarm of thin aerial
shapes appears, And, flutt'ring round his

10741.text:
temples, deafs his ears: These he consults,
the future fates to know, From pow'rs above,

10749.text:
and from the fiends below. Here, for the gods'
advice, Latinus flies, Off'ring a hundred

10757.text:
sheep for sacrifice: Their woolly fleeces,
as the rites requir'd, He laid beneath him,

10763.text:
and to rest retir'd. No sooner were his eyes
in slumber bound, When, from above, a more

10771.text:
than mortal sound Invades his ears; and thus
the vision spoke: "Seek not, my seed, in Latian

10782.text:
bands to yoke Our fair Lavinia, nor the gods
provoke. A foreign son upon thy shore descends,

10793.text:
Whose martial fame from pole to pole extends.
His race, in arms and arts of peace renown'd,

10802.text:
Not Latium shall contain, nor Europe bound:
'T is theirs whate'er the sun surveys around."

10812.text:
These answers, in the silent night receiv'd,
The king himself divulg'd, the land believ'd:

10817.text:
The fame thro' all the neighb'ring nations
flew, When now the Trojan navy was in view.

10825.text:
Beneath a shady tree, the hero spread His
table on the turf, with cakes of bread; And,

10833.text:
with his chiefs, on forest fruits he fed.
They sate; and, (not without the god's command,)

10840.text:
Their homely fare dispatch'd, the hungry band
Invade their trenchers next, and soon devour,

10847.text:
To mend the scanty meal, their cakes of flour.
Ascanius this observ'd, and smiling said:

10855.text:
"See, we devour the plates on which we fed."
The speech had omen, that the Trojan race

10862.text:
Should find repose, and this the time and
place. Aeneas took the word, and thus replies,

10869.text:
Confessing fate with wonder in his eyes: "All
hail, O earth! all hail, my household gods!

10881.text:
Behold the destin'd place of your abodes!
For thus Anchises prophesied of old, And this

10887.text:
our fatal place of rest foretold: 'When, on
a foreign shore, instead of meat, By famine

10896.text:
forc'd, your trenchers you shall eat, Then
ease your weary Trojans will attend, And the

10904.text:
long labors of your voyage end. Remember on
that happy coast to build, And with a trench

10911.text:
inclose the fruitful field.' This was that
famine, this the fatal place Which ends the

10919.text:
wand'ring of our exil'd race. Then, on to-morrow's
dawn, your care employ, To search the land,

10928.text:
and where the cities lie, And what the men;
but give this day to joy. Now pour to Jove;

10936.text:
and, after Jove is blest, Call great Anchises
to the genial feast: Crown high the goblets

10943.text:
with a cheerful draught; Enjoy the present
hour; adjourn the future thought." Thus having

10951.text:
said, the hero bound his brows With leafy
branches, then perform'd his vows; Adoring

10959.text:
first the genius of the place, Then Earth,
the mother of the heav'nly race, The nymphs,

10965.text:
and native godheads yet unknown, And Night,
and all the stars that gild her sable throne,

10974.text:
And ancient Cybel, and Idaean Jove, And last
his sire below, and mother queen above. Then

10979.text:
heav'n's high monarch thunder'd thrice aloud,
And thrice he shook aloft a golden cloud.

10987.text:
Soon thro' the joyful camp a rumor flew, The
time was come their city to renew. Then ev'ry

10994.text:
brow with cheerful green is crown'd, The feasts
are doubled, and the bowls go round. When

11003.text:
next the rosy morn disclos'd the day, The
scouts to sev'ral parts divide their way,

11009.text:
To learn the natives' names, their towns explore,
The coasts and trendings of the crooked shore:

11017.text:
Here Tiber flows, and here Numicus stands;
Here warlike Latins hold the happy lands.

11027.text:
The pious chief, who sought by peaceful ways
To found his empire, and his town to raise,

11034.text:
A hundred youths from all his train selects,
And to the Latian court their course directs,

11040.text:
(The spacious palace where their prince resides,)
And all their heads with wreaths of olive

11047.text:
hides. They go commission'd to require a peace,
And carry presents to procure access. Thus

11054.text:
while they speed their pace, the prince designs
His new-elected seat, and draws the lines.

11062.text:
The Trojans round the place a rampire cast,
And palisades about the trenches plac'd. Meantime

11070.text:
the train, proceeding on their way, From far
the town and lofty tow'rs survey; At length

11077.text:
approach the walls. Without the gate, They
see the boys and Latian youth debate The martial

11084.text:
prizes on the dusty plain: Some drive the
cars, and some the coursers rein; Some bend

11092.text:
the stubborn bow for victory, And some with
darts their active sinews try. A posting messenger,

11100.text:
dispatch'd from hence, Of this fair troop
advis'd their aged prince, That foreign men

11106.text:
of mighty stature came; Uncouth their habit,
and unknown their name. The king ordains their

11114.text:
entrance, and ascends His regal seat, surrounded
by his friends. The palace built by Picus,

11124.text:
vast and proud, Supported by a hundred pillars
stood, And round incompass'd with a rising

11131.text:
wood. The pile o'erlook'd the town, and drew
the sight; Surpris'd at once with reverence

11139.text:
and delight. There kings receiv'd the marks
of sov'reign pow'r; In state the monarchs

11145.text:
march'd; the lictors bore Their awful axes
and the rods before. Here the tribunal stood,

11154.text:
the house of pray'r, And here the sacred senators
repair; All at large tables, in long order

11162.text:
set, A ram their off'ring, and a ram their
meat. Above the portal, carv'd in cedar wood,

11171.text:
Plac'd in their ranks, their godlike grandsires
stood; Old Saturn, with his crooked scythe,

11178.text:
on high; And Italus, that led the colony;
And ancient Janus, with his double face, And

11187.text:
bunch of keys, the porter of the place. There
good Sabinus, planter of the vines, On a short

11195.text:
pruning hook his head reclines, And studiously
surveys his gen'rous wines; Then warlike kings,

11205.text:
who for their country fought, And honorable
wounds from battle brought. Around the posts

11213.text:
hung helmets, darts, and spears, And captive
chariots, axes, shields, and bars, And broken

11223.text:
beaks of ships, the trophies of their wars.
Above the rest, as chief of all the band,

11231.text:
Was Picus plac'd, a buckler in his hand; His
other wav'd a long divining wand. Girt in

11240.text:
his Gabin gown the hero sate, Yet could not
with his art avoid his fate: For Circe long

11247.text:
had lov'd the youth in vain, Till love, refus'd,
converted to disdain: Then, mixing pow'rful

11255.text:
herbs, with magic art, She chang'd his form,
who could not change his heart; Constrain'd

11263.text:
him in a bird, and made him fly, With party-color'd
plumes, a chatt'ring pie. In this high temple,

11273.text:
on a chair of state, The seat of audience,
old Latinus sate; Then gave admission to the

11280.text:
Trojan train; And thus with pleasing accents
he began: "Tell me, ye Trojans, for that name

11288.text:
you own, Nor is your course upon our coasts
unknown- Say what you seek, and whither were

11297.text:
you bound: Were you by stress of weather cast
aground? (Such dangers as on seas are often

11305.text:
seen, And oft befall to miserable men,) Or
come, your shipping in our ports to lay, Spent

11314.text:
and disabled in so long a way? Say what you
want: the Latians you shall find Not forc'd

11322.text:
to goodness, but by will inclin'd; For, since
the time of Saturn's holy reign, His hospitable

11330.text:
customs we retain. I call to mind (but time
the tale has worn) Th' Arunci told, that Dardanus,

11338.text:
tho' born On Latian plains, yet sought the
Phrygian shore, And Samothracia, Samos call'd

11346.text:
before. From Tuscan Coritum he claim'd his
birth; But after, when exempt from mortal

11354.text:
earth, From thence ascended to his kindred
skies, A god, and, as a god, augments their

11363.text:
sacrifice," He said. Ilioneus made this reply:
"O king, of Faunus' royal family! Nor wintry

11371.text:
winds to Latium forc'd our way, Nor did the
stars our wand'ring course betray. Willing

11379.text:
we sought your shores; and, hither bound,
The port, so long desir'd, at length we found;

11387.text:
From our sweet homes and ancient realms expell'd;
Great as the greatest that the sun beheld.

11394.text:
The god began our line, who rules above; And,
as our race, our king descends from Jove:

11403.text:
And hither are we come, by his command, To
crave admission in your happy land. How dire

11411.text:
a tempest, from Mycenae pour'd, Our plains,
our temples, and our town devour'd; What was

11417.text:
the waste of war, what fierce alarms Shook
Asia's crown with European arms; Ev'n such

11424.text:
have heard, if any such there be, Whose earth
is bounded by the frozen sea; And such as,

11431.text:
born beneath the burning sky And sultry sun,
betwixt the tropics lie. From that dire deluge,

11439.text:
thro' the wat'ry waste, Such length of years,
such various perils past, At last escap'd,

11448.text:
to Latium we repair, To beg what you without
your want may spare: The common water, and

11457.text:
the common air; Sheds which ourselves will
build, and mean abodes, Fit to receive and

11464.text:
serve our banish'd gods. Nor our admission
shall your realm disgrace, Nor length of time

11473.text:
our gratitude efface. Besides, what endless
honor you shall gain, To save and shelter

11482.text:
Troy's unhappy train! Now, by my sov'reign,
and his fate, I swear, Renown'd for faith

11489.text:
in peace, for force in war; Oft our alliance
other lands desir'd, And, what we seek of

11501.text:
you, of us requir'd. Despite not then, that
in our hands we bear These holy boughs, sue

11510.text:
with words of pray'r. Fate and the gods, by
their supreme command, Have doom'd our ships

11517.text:
to seek the Latian land. To these abodes our
fleet Apollo sends; Here Dardanus was born,

11525.text:
and hither tends; Where Tuscan Tiber rolls
with rapid force, And where Numicus opes his

11532.text:
holy source. Besides, our prince presents,
with his request, Some small remains of what

11539.text:
his sire possess'd. This golden charger, snatch'd
from burning Troy, Anchises did in sacrifice

11548.text:
employ; This royal robe and this tiara wore
Old Priam, and this golden scepter bore In

11557.text:
full assemblies, and in solemn games; These
purple vests were weav'd by Dardan dames."

11566.text:
Thus while he spoke, Latinus roll'd around
His eyes, and fix'd a while upon the ground.

11571.text:
Intent he seem'd, and anxious in his breast;
Not by the scepter mov'd, or kingly vest,

11577.text:
But pond'ring future things of wondrous weight;
Succession, empire, and his daughter's fate.

11585.text:
On these he mus'd within his thoughtful mind,
And then revolv'd what Faunus had divin'd.

11593.text:
This was the foreign prince, by fate decreed
To share his scepter, and Lavinia's bed; This

11600.text:
was the race that sure portents foreshew To
sway the world, and land and sea subdue. At

11609.text:
length he rais'd his cheerful head, and spoke:
"The pow'rs," said he, "the pow'rs we both

11615.text:
invoke, To you, and yours, and mine, propitious
be, And firm our purpose with their augury!

11625.text:
Have what you ask; your presents I receive;
Land, where and when you please, with ample

11632.text:
leave; Partake and use my kingdom as your
own; All shall be yours, while I command the

11641.text:
crown: And, if my wish'd alliance please your
king, Tell him he should not send the peace,

11647.text:
but bring. Then let him not a friend's embraces
fear; The peace is made when I behold him

11655.text:
here. Besides this answer, tell my royal guest,
I add to his commands my own request: One

11663.text:
only daughter heirs my crown and state, Whom
not our oracles, nor Heav'n, nor fate, Nor

11670.text:
frequent prodigies, permit to join With any
native of th' Ausonian line. A foreign son-in-law

11678.text:
shall come from far (Such is our doom), a
chief renown'd in war, Whose race shall bear

11685.text:
aloft the Latian name, And thro' the conquer'd
world diffuse our fame. Himself to be the

11692.text:
man the fates require, I firmly judge, and,
what I judge, desire." He said, and then on

11701.text:
each bestow'd a steed. Three hundred horses,
in high stables fed, Stood ready, shining

11708.text:
all, and smoothly dress'd: Of these he chose
the fairest and the best, To mount the Trojan

11714.text:
troop. At his command The steeds caparison'd
with purple stand, With golden trappings,

11722.text:
glorious to behold, And champ betwixt their
teeth the foaming gold. Then to his absent

11729.text:
guest the king decreed A pair of coursers
born of heav'nly breed, Who from their nostrils

11735.text:
breath'd ethereal fire; Whom Circe stole from
her celestial sire, By substituting mares

11743.text:
produc'd on earth, Whose wombs conceiv'd a
more than mortal birth. These draw the chariot

11750.text:
which Latinus sends, And the rich present
to the prince commends. Sublime on stately

11757.text:
steeds the Trojans borne, To their expecting
lord with peace return. But jealous Juno,

11765.text:
from Pachynus' height, As she from Argos took
her airy flight, Beheld with envious eyes

11772.text:
this hateful sight. She saw the Trojan and
his joyful train Descend upon the shore, desert

11779.text:
the main, Design a town, and, with unhop'd
success, Th' embassadors return with promis'd

11787.text:
peace. Then, pierc'd with pain, she shook
her haughty head, Sigh'd from her inward soul,

11793.text:
and thus she said: "O hated offspring of my
Phrygian foes! O fates of Troy, which Juno's

11803.text:
fates oppose! Could they not fall unpitied
on the plain, But slain revive, and, taken,

11811.text:
scape again? When execrable Troy in ashes
lay, Thro' fires and swords and seas they

11818.text:
forc'd their way. Then vanquish'd Juno must
in vain contend, Her rage disarm'd, her empire

11827.text:
at an end. Breathless and tir'd, is all my
fury spent? Or does my glutted spleen at length

11836.text:
relent? As if 't were little from their town
to chase, I thro' the seas pursued their exil'd

11843.text:
race; Ingag'd the heav'ns, oppos'd the stormy
main; But billows roar'd, and tempests rag'd

11854.text:
in vain. What have my Scyllas and my Syrtes
done, When these they overpass, and those

11859.text:
they shun? On Tiber's shores they land, secure
of fate, Triumphant o'er the storms and Juno's

11867.text:
hate. Mars could in mutual blood the Centaurs
bathe, And Jove himself gave way to Cynthia's

11872.text:
wrath, Who sent the tusky boar to Calydon;
(What great offense had either people done?)

11878.text:
But I, the consort of the Thunderer, Have
wag'd a long and unsuccessful war, With various

11887.text:
arts and arms in vain have toil'd, And by
a mortal man at length am foil'd. If native

11894.text:
pow'r prevail not, shall I doubt To seek for
needful succor from without? If Jove and Heav'n
